{{short description|Outbreaks of plague in Madagascar during the 21st century}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} Madagascar has experienced two outbreaks of bubonic and pneumonic plague in the 21st century. In 2014, 40 died, and in 2017, 221 died.
{{Infobox event|cause=[[bubonic plague|bubonic]] and [[pneumonic plague]]|coordinates=<!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} -->|date={{start date|df=yes|2014|08|31}}– {{end date|df=yes|2014|11|16}}|image=Madagascar - Location Map (2013) - MDG - UNOCHA.svg|notes=as of 16 November 2014|outcome=119 confirmed cases|place=[[Madagascar]]|reported deaths=40|title=2014 Madagascar plague outbreak}}
{{Infobox event | title = 2017 Madagascar plague outbreak | image = Madagascar - Location Map (2013) - MDG - UNOCHA.svg | image_size = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | date = {{start date|df=yes|2017|08|27}} – early 2018 | place = [[Madagascar]] | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | also known as = | cause = [[Bubonic plague|Bubonic]] and [[pneumonic plague]] | outcome = 2575 (suspected, probable, confirmed cases) | reported deaths = 221 (CFR 8.6%) | burial = | inquiries = | litigation = | website = | notes = as of 15 December 2017<ref>{{cite web|title=Weekly Bulletin on Outbreaks and Other Emergencies|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/259709/1/OEW50-1015122017.pdf|website=WHO Africa|accessdate=23 January 2018}}</ref> }}
== History ==
=== 2014 === An outbreak of [[Plague (disease)|plague]] in [[Madagascar]] in 2014 started on 31 August. On that day the first case, a man from [[Soamahamanina]] village in [[Tsiroanomandidy]], was identified.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/21-november-2014-plague/en/|title=Plague - Madagascar|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The patient died on 3 September.<ref name=":4" /> The outbreak is in the form of [[Bubonic plague|bubonic]] and [[pneumonic plague]]. By 16 November 2014, a total of 119 cases had been confirmed, including 40 deaths.<ref name=":4" /> Two percent of reported cases were of the pneumonic form. By 21 November, in the capital [[Antananarivo]] there were two confirmed cases, including one death.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-30152979|title=Madagascar plague outbreak kills 40, says WHO|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
On 4 November 2014, the Ministry of Health of Madagascar reported the outbreak to the [[World Health Organization]].<ref name=":4" />
=== 2017 === A more recent outbreak of [[plague (disease)|plague]] in [[Madagascar]] began in August 2017 and expanded rapidly, with about two-thirds of cases transmitted person-to-person as [[pneumonic plague]], the most dangerous form of the disease.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/madagascar/madagascar-plague-outbreak-external-situation-report-5-20-october-2017|title=Madagascar Plague Outbreak: External Situation Report #5 - 20 October 2017|date=21 October 2017|website=ReliefWeb|language=English|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref> The death toll of 124 by 20 October exceeded that of [[2014 Madagascar plague outbreak|previous outbreaks]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2017/10/25/world/africa/25reuters-madagascar-plague.html?_r=0|title=Plague Kills 124 in Madagascar, Cities Most Affected: Report|date=25 October 2017|website=The New York Times|accessdate=26 October 2017}}</ref> More than half of cases have been recorded in the capital of Antananarivo and the main port of Toamasina, the largest cities in Madagascar. Nine nearby countries were considered at high risk of a similar outbreak.<ref name="sciencemag">{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencemagazinedigital.org/sciencemagazine/27_october_2017_Main?sub_id=PXTGnKLZnZnu&u1=41549201&folio=430&pg=14#pg14|title=Echoes of Ebola as plague hits Madagascar. Science Magazine - October 27, 2017 - 14|website=www.sciencemagazinedigital.org|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref> The outbreak appeared to peak in Mid-October with the number of new cases declining.<ref name="McNeil2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/02/health/plague-madagascar.html|title=Deadly Plague Outbreak in Madagascar Appears to Wane|last1=Jr|first1=Donald G. McNeil|date=2 November 2017|website=The New York Times|accessdate=25 November 2017}}</ref> Typically the annual plague outbreak peaks in December and runs until April.
On 2 November, a [[ProMED-mail]] moderator expressed surprise at the considerable variation reported in numbers of cases and deaths, especially with the relatively low case-fatality rate (CFR) considering that pneumomic plague is reported to account for over 60 percent of deaths.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.promedmail.org/post/5420572|title=Plague - Madagascar (28): fatal, WHO 2017-11-02 15:20:33|website=www.promedmail.org|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|language=en|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref> An article from the [[World Health Organization]] reported more than 1800 cases as of late October, while nearly 500 fewer had been reported in the week previously.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/features/2017/madagascar-plague-risk/en/|title=Madagascar plague: mitigating the risk of regional spread|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref>
In January 2018 the experts declared the outbreak over as no new cases had been reported since November 2017, although the World health organization stated that there was a "moderate" chance or re-occurrence. Malagasy Prime Minister [[Olivier Mahafaly Solonandrasana]] had declared the crisis over on 23 November 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.travelweekly.co.uk/articles/294923/madagascar-declares-the-end-of-plague-epidemic|title=Madagascar declares the end of plague epidemic|last=Ireland|first=Ben|date=3 January 2018|publisher=Travel Weekly|accessdate=26 March 2018}}</ref>
=== August === The outbreak began in August 2017 with the death from pneumonic plague of a 31-year-old man who had been traveling in a crowded minibus toward the capital city of Antananarivo in the central highlands.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.livescience.com/60715-plague-outbreak-madagascar.html|title=How the Plague Outbreak in Madagascar Got So Bad, So Fast|website=Live Science|accessdate=21 October 2017}}</ref> The outbreak expanded rapidly, transmitted person-to-person in the pneumonic form of the disease, which accounted for more than 60 percent of cases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/handle/10665/259385|title=Plague Outbreak Madagascar External Situation Report 07|last1=Programme|first1=World Health Organization. Regional Office for Africa, Health Emergencies|date=2017|publisher=World Health Organization. Regional Office for Africa, Health Emergencies Programme|language=en|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref> Scientists discovered three new strains of ''Y. pestis'' in Madagascar in 2017. Additionally, one strain of ''Y. pestis'' was found to be resistant to antibiotic treatment.<ref name=":6">Riehm, J. M., Projahn, M., Vogler, A. J., Rajerison, M., Andersen, G., Hall, C. M., ... & Nottingham, R. (2017). Diverse genotypes of Yersinia pestis caused plague in Madagascar in 2007. ''PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases'', ''9''(6), e0003844.</ref> Because of plague moving from rural to urban areas, there is increased risk for transmission to other countries. Urban areas that are a major transportation hub for shipping and recreation are at high risk for transmitting plague to nearby countries.
=== September–October === The outbreak was initially recognized on 11 September by local authorities and confirmed by the [[Pasteur Institute|Institut Pasteur de Madagascar]]. Authorities called the outbreak "quite worrisome" because the number of cases per day was growing rapidly, and many cases were in urban areas where there are more opportunities for contact between people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.promedmail.org/post/5389292|title=PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (21): FATAL, NUMBERS GROWING, WHO, MINISTRY OF HEALTH|website=www.promedmail.org|language=en|accessdate=21 October 2017}}</ref> Panic was reported in the capital, with the main hospital overcrowded with cases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/africa/la-fg-madagascar-plague-20171013-htmlstory.html|title=The Black Death is killing people: Why is Madagascar facing its worst plague outbreak in years?|website=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=21 October 2017}}</ref> The death toll in this outbreak had by mid-October exceeded an outbreak [[2014 Madagascar plague outbreak|in 2014]]. Most cases were of the pneumonic form. The bubonic form, transmitted by the bites of fleas from rodents, is more usual in the annual outbreaks in Madagascar. The government announced they had "temporarily suspended gatherings to the general public in places where the traceability of the participants is difficult if not impossible (stadiums, sports palaces, gymnasiums …)".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://outbreaknewstoday.com/madagascar-plague-outbreak-case-count-reaches-500/|title=Madagascar plague outbreak case count reaches 500 - Outbreak News Today|date=11 October 2017|website=Outbreak News Today|accessdate=21 October 2017}}</ref>
=== November === By 8 November, deaths had risen to 165 with infections totalling over 2000, however the rate of spread had slowed, raising hope that the outbreak was starting to come under control. Concerns continued to be raised that plague might still spread to neighboring countries, or mutate to a form that could be more difficult to treat.<ref>[https://amp.cnn.com/cnn/2017/11/13/health/plague-madagascar-decline/index.html Plague on decline in Madagascar, but 9 countries on alert. CNN News, 13 November 2017]</ref> By 15 November, there had been 171 deaths and 2119 total cases of plague, however no new infections had been reported since 28 October.<ref>[http://www.who.int/csr/don/15-november-2017-plague-madagascar/en/ World Health Organisation. Plague – Madagascar. Disease outbreak news. 15 November 2017]</ref>
== Background == Plague is caused by the bacterium ''Yersinia pesti'' and is most commonly transmitted through infected fleas.<ref>Raoult, D., Mouffok, N., Bitam, I., Piarroux, R., & Drancourt, M. (2013). Plague: history and contemporary analysis. ''Journal of Infection'', ''66''(1), 18-26.</ref> There are three types of plague: bubonic, pneumonic and septicemic. Bubonic plague is the most well-known type. This type of plague results in swollen lymph nodes that are called buboes. This type of plague is treatable with antibiotics, but if not treated effectively, the infection can spread to different parts of the body. Pneumonic plague occurs when plague infects the lungs and is transmissible person to person through infected droplets. This form of plague is very deadly. Septicemic plague occurs when plague enters the blood. Skin and tissues turn black and die, and bleeding into skin and organs often occurs. This form of plague is also deadly. Pneumonic plague and septicemic plague often occur when bubonic plague goes untreated and are difficult to diagnose.<ref name=":0">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (2018). Plague. 2018.</ref>
=== Endemic plague === Plague has endemically resided in Madagascar since it was first brought to the island from India in 1898, on the [[Central Highlands (Madagascar)|central high plateau of Madagascar]], usually occurring every year as a seasonal upsurge during the rainy season.<ref name=":2">Andrianaivoarimanana, V., Kreppel, K., Elissa, N., Duplantier, J. M., Carniel, E., Rajerison, M., & Jambou, R. (2013). Understanding the persistence of plague foci in Madagascar. ''PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases'', ''7''(11), e2382.</ref> Plague resides in Madagascar similar to the way flu resides in the United States. "Plague season" is generally October through March, and mostly affects rural areas of Madagascar.<ref name=":0" /> Plague, although endemic, has been relatively dormant in Madagascar until 1990. Annually until then, there were about 20-30 cases reported a year. Recently, however, the annual number of cases has risen to typically between 800 and 1500 a year.<ref name=":1">World Health Organization (2018). Plague – Madagascar. 2018.</ref> All cases of plague must be reported to the Ministry of Health; however, cases often go underreported due to lack of quality epidemiologic resources in rural areas. Tests for plague used in these areas often have low sensitivity and are unreliable.<ref name=":5">Miarinjara, A., & Boyer, S. (2016). Current perspectives on plague vector control in Madagascar: Susceptibility status of Xenopsylla cheopis to 12 insecticides. ''PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases'', ''10''(2), e0004414.</ref> In the past, cases of plague in Madagascar have been bubonic and not transmittable person to person. The increase in plague cases over the last 20 years have been largely due to an increase in pneumonic plague.<ref name=":1" /> Pneumonic plague is transmitted person to person via infected droplets. It is often difficult to diagnose and by the time it is diagnosed, cases are usually fatal. Case fatality rate of pneumonic plague in Madagascar is close to 75%.<ref name=":0" />
=== Confounding factors ===
==== Rural to urban ==== When an endemic disease, such as Ebola or plague, is introduced to a new geographic area that is densely populated with international shipping routes, it increases transmission rates and leads to severe outbreaks and potential pandemics. Although urban areas like Antananarvio and Mahajanga are more affluent, they are still impoverished in global comparison. Insufficient waste management, lack of clean water, and poor infrastructure are all issues that are breeding grounds for rats and fleas and therefore perpetuate plague transmission in urban areas.<ref name=":5"/> Furthermore, the rat-to-flea cycle of transmission has not changed since the first pandemic of plague. This type of consistency allows the organism to become more infectious.
==== Rats and fleas ==== High rates of plague transmission have been associated with low rat abundance and high volume of flea vectors.<ref name=":2" /> Historically, rats who acted as hosts to the flea vector subsequently died once they were infected with plague. However, the organism evolved and scientists are now finding that rats are not dying from plague. This means that plague survives longer in the host and allows for the bacteria to live longer and potentially infect more people. Scientists discovered three new strains of ''Y. pestis'' in Madagascar in 2017. Additionally, one strain of ''Y. pestis'' was found to be resistant to antibiotic treatment.<ref name=":6" /> Because of plague moving from rural to urban areas, there is increased risk for transmission to other countries. Urban areas that are a major transportation hub for shipping and recreation are at high risk for transmitting plague to nearby countries. The elevation of the mountains where most of the agriculture takes place, in addition to the ideal climate that allows rats and fleas to prosper, scientists have seen plague thrive in Madagascar’s climate compared to other countries where there is endemic plague. During this plague season, rats and fleas infect the soil.
==== Evolution of bacteria ==== Scientists discovered three new strains of ''Y. pestis'' in Madagascar in 2017. Additionally, one strain of ''Y. pestis'' was found to be resistant to antibiotic treatment.<ref name=":6" /> Because of plague moving from rural to urban areas, there is increased risk for transmission to other countries. Urban areas that are a major transportation hub for shipping and recreation are at high risk for transmitting plague to nearby countries. This is how Ebola spread into a global pandemic.
==== Agriculture ==== Plague in Madagascar is predominantly a rural disease related to agricultural activities. Plague "season" (October through April) coincides with the hot and rainy season in the agricultural highlands. Rats do not thrive in cold climate, and therefore are more prevalent during this time of year. Rice is a vital crop in Madagascar, and due to the high prevalence of fleas and rats in agricultural areas, plague bacteria often infects crops and soil. Many scientists have found that the plague bacteria ''Y. pestis'' can live in soil for months at a time.<ref name=":3">Chanteau, S., Ratsifasoamanana, L., Rasoamanana, B., Rahalison, L., Randriambelosoa, J., Roux, J....Rabeson, D. (1998). Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. ''Emerging Infectious Diseases'', ''4''(1), 101-104. <nowiki>https://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid0401.980114</nowiki>.</ref>
==== Burial practices ==== In addition to agricultural factors that increase prevalence of plague, burial practices in Madagascar also spread disease. Famadihana is a burial practice in Madagascar that is practiced among the Malagasy people. It is commonly known as "turning of the bones." Family members exhume their deceased family members from the family crypts and wrap them up in fresh cloth. Then, they dance around the crypt with the body to live music. This custom is based on a belief that the dead do not join the rest of their ancestors until their body reaches full decomposition with appropriate ceremonies. This process could take up to several years and involves direct contact with corpses. This burial practice perpetuates the spread of plague among other diseases.<ref>Ramasindrazana, B., Andrianaivoarimanana, V., Rakotondramanga, J. M., Birdsell, D. N., Ratsitorahina, M., & Rajerison, M. (2017). Pneumonic Plague Transmission, Moramanga, Madagascar, 2015. ''Emerging Infectious Diseases'', ''23''(3), 521.</ref>
==== Poverty ==== Plague is symptomatic of poverty. Rats and fleas thrive in rural and urban areas of Madagascar due to the impoverishment of the country. Lack of proper infrastructure, lack of sanitation and waste removal, little clean water, and scarce health facilities create a perfect breeding ground for rats and fleas to thrive.<ref>Migliani, R., Chanteau, S., Rahalison, L., Ratsitorahina, M., Boutin, J. P., Ratsifasoamanana, L., & Roux, J. (2006). Epidemiological trends for human plague in Madagascar during the second half of the 20th century: a survey of 20 900 notified cases. ''Tropical Medicine & International Health'', ''11''(8), 1228-1237.</ref> Although plague is prevalent in other countries, Madagascar has the highest fatality and accounts for 30% of all plague cases largely due poverty and lack of health resources like antibiotics and proper testing. Furthermore, outbreaks of plague have become increasingly more severe due to bubonic plague going untreated and developing into pneumonic plague. Once plague becomes pneumonic, it is significantly more contagious and is transmittable person to person.<ref name=":1" />
=== Severity === Recently, plague outbreaks have become increasingly more severe. The most recent outbreak in August 2017 is the worst to date with over 1,800 confirmed cases of plague. Of these confirmed cases, 1,100 of them were cases of pneumonic plague. 114 districts of Madagascar were affected by the plague outbreak. Usually, endemic plague only affects around 20 rural districts (WHO, 2017.<ref name=":1" /> This outbreak was different in nature due to the fact that the plague shifted from rural geographic location to urban geographic location. Plague was found in major shipping ports like Mahajanga and in the capital Antananarvio. The capital alone is home to 2.7 million people.<ref name=":3" /> Plague moving into urban areas increased transmission rates due to the high volume of people living in these areas and the amount of trade traffic that occurs on a daily basis.
==Response to the disease== Madagascar proposed a National Plague Control Program, which is a surveillance program run by the government and the Ministry of Health that is based on immediate notification of every suspected case of plague. Every case reported to the National Plague Control Program is treated with antibiotics. In addition to this course of treatment, insecticide is brought to the home or work for flea control. Although the ideas and intentions of the National Plague Control Program are great and in theory could be very beneficial to treating and preventing outbreaks of plague. However, severe economic limitations make the execution of this program less than ideal. Furthermore, disparities in rural areas compared to urban areas make accessibility and testing in rural areas challenging.<ref name=":5" /> Economic resources need to be strengthened before this program can live up to its full potential. After the most recent, major outbreak, the WHO created a Crisis Emergency Committee to monitor the situation. They deployed epidemiologists, doctors, and risk management coordinators in order to coordinate surveillance, facilitate tracing contacts, oversee case management, administer isolation protocol, and distribute supplies. In addition to the new committee, Madagascar reallocated funds in order to help with isolation, treatment, and supplies.<ref name=":1" /> These solutions to the outbreak helped, as cases of plague declined and hospitalized patients decreased in volume. However, now that the major outbreaks have been handled, how do we continue to mitigate the burden of disease in these rural areas? Why is it that resources and funds are allocated only when outbreaks occur in dense, urban areas? How do we take steps to prevent against the next major outbreak? These are the questions that need to be answered and then action needs to be taken in order to reduce disparity among rural areas where plague is most prevalent.
==Other countries== Twelve more cases of suspected plague appeared in the [[Seychelles]] days after the death of a 34-year-old male who had recently traveled to Madagascar and who was confirmed as having pneumonic plague on 10 October.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jr|first1=Donald G. McNeil|title=Seychelles Reports a Case of Plague|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/11/health/plague-seychelles-madagascar.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=21 October 2017|date=11 October 2017}}</ref> Air Seychelles suspended all flights to Madagascar.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.seychellesnewsagency.com/articles/8022/Air+Seychelles+suspends+flights+to+Madagascar+after+plague+outbreak|title=Air Seychelles suspends flights to Madagascar after plague outbreak|date=6 October 2017|accessdate=24 October 2017|publisher=Seychelles news agency}}</ref> More sophisticated tests later showed that the infection was not plague.<ref name=McNeil2017/>
A South African basketball player who contracted plague while attending a tournament in Madagascar was successfully treated and returned home.<ref>{{cite web|title=South African successfully treated after contracting plague|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2017-10-12-south-african-successfully-treated-after-contracting-plague/|publisher=TimesLive|accessdate=21 October 2017}}</ref> The type of plague the player had was not reported, but one of the cases in the Seychelles who died of pneumonic plague was thought to have attended the same tournament.<ref>{{cite web|title=Published Date: 2017-10-12 12:46:43 Subject: <PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (17): South Africa (ex Madagascar) RFI|url=https://www.promedmail.org/post/5375932|website=www.promedmail.org|accessdate=21 October 2017|language=en}}</ref>
The World Health Organization warned that there was a high risk the disease could spread to nine other countries in Africa and the Indian Ocean (Ethiopia, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, South Africa, Seychelles, Comoros, Reunion, and Mauritius) because of frequent trade and travel with Madagascar.<ref name=sciencemag/>

'''Alternating occlusion training''', also referred to as '''electronic rapid alternate occlusion''', is an approach to [[amblyopia]] and to intermittent central [[Suppression (eye)|suppression]] in [[vision therapy]], in which electronic devices such as programmable [[Active shutter 3D system|shutter glasses or goggles]] are used to block the field of view of one eye in rapid alternation.
When performing alternating occlusion training, the person wears the occlusion goggles continuously for several hours while performing regular everyday activities. Wearing the device encourages or forces the alternating use of both eyes, similar to eye patching, but rapidly alternating in time. The aim is to circumvent the tendency to suppress the field of view of the weaker eye and to train the capacity for [[binocular vision]].
Traditionally, [[eye patch]]es are used to block the field of view of one eye. [[Strabismus|Strabismic]] or [[amblyopia|amblyopic]] children are often required to wear an eye patch for hours or days. The use of the patch generally alternates on a daily or weekly basis between the two eyes, with a long time duration for the patching of the stronger eye and a shorter time duration, if any, for the patching of the weaker eye. In contrast to eye patching, training with occlusion goggles allows to use rapid rates of alternation.
== Flicker rates == The flicker rates at which the occlusion is alternated between the two eyes in alternating occlusion training are generally much slower than those employed by the widespread active shutter 3D glasses for viewing 3D television or cinema.
Therapeutic procedures have been proposed in which the active eye is switched after a duration of many seconds (for example, with an ON (occlusion) duration of 40 seconds and an OFF state (open) duration of 20 seconds of each minute<ref name="spierer-etal-2010">{{cite news|author1=Abraham Spierer|author2=Judith Raz|author3=Omry BenEzra|author4=Rafi Herzog|author5=Evelyne Cohen|author6=Ilana Karshai|author7=David BenEzra|url=http://www.iovs.org/content/51/7/3395.full|title=Treating Amblyopia with Liquid Crystal Glasses: A Pilot Study|journal=Invest. Ophthalmol. Vis. Sci.|date=July 2010|volume=51|number=7|pages=3395–3398|doi=10.1167/iovs.09-4568}}</ref>); others propose a much faster flicker rate of approximately 5 Hz.<ref name="hussey-2007">{{cite news|author=Eric S. Hussey|title=A pilot study on the geographically remote treatment of intermittent central suppression using electronic rapid alternate occlusion|journal=Journal of Behavioural Optometry (JBO)|year=2007|volume=18|number=1|pages=10–14}} ([http://www.oepf.org/journal/pdf/jbo-volume-18-issue-1-treatment-intermittent-central-supression-using-erac abstract], [http://www.oepf.org/sites/default/files/journals/jbo-volume-18-issue-1/18-1%20Hussey.pdf full text PDF])</ref>
An alternating occlusion device (the so-called ''Translid Binocular Interaction Trainer'' (TBIS) operating at a rate of 9 to 11 Hz) was introduced by Merrill Allen in 1967 to favor parallel processing of the eyes.<ref>Merrill J. Allen, [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6065440 Shock treatment for visual rehabilitation], Journal of the American Optometric Association, August 1967, volume 38, number 8, pages 661-662 (referenced here as citation only), and Merrill J. Allen, Opt. J. Rev. Optom. 1969 as cited by: {{cite news|author=Joseph N. Trachtmann|title=Learning Problems: Theoretical and Practical Considerations of Information Processing|journal=Journal of Behavioural Optometry (JBO)|year=2000|volume=11|number=2|pages=35–39}} ([http://www.oepf.org/journal/pdf/jbo-volume-11-issue-2-learning-problems-theoretical-and-practical-considerations-informa abstract], [http://www.oepf.org/sites/default/files/journals/jbo-volume-11-issue-2/11-2%20Trachtman.pdf full text PDF])</ref>
The flicker rate is crucial with relation to potential side effects and may possibly be relevant for the efficacy of the training. It has been suggested that the flickering sequence could be adapted to suit the depth of amblyopia, the required duration of treatment, the age of the patient, or could be adapted dynamically according to the visual function behavior of the amblyopic eye.<ref name="spierer-etal-2010"/>
== Side-effects and potential risks == Reported results of the use of alternating occlusion devices include improved vision, as well as occasional side effects of headaches or discomfort.<ref name="spierer-etal-2010"/><ref name="hussey-2007"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Eric S. Hussey|url=http://www.optometryjaoa.com/article/S1529-1839%2811%2900504-5/abstract|title=Remote treatment of intermittent central suppression improves quality-of-life measures|journal=Optometry - Journal of the American Optometric Association|volume=83|number=1|pages=19–26|date=January 2012}}</ref> The purchase of such an electronic LCD may require written permission by the patient's optometrist.<ref>[http://www.oepf.org/product/electronic-rapid-alternate-occlusion-goggles Electronic Rapid Alternate Occlusion Goggles], Optometric Extension Program Foundation (OEPF), downloaded 20 August 2013</ref>
It was found that the flicker rates of 9 to 11 Hz that were employed in the TBIS device are slow enough and the stimulus weak enough to avoid any risk of epileptic seizure.<ref name="AllenWeintraub2008">{{cite book|author1=Merrill J. Allen|author2=Leslie Weintraub|author3=Bernard S. Abrams|title=Forensic Vision With Application to Highway Safety|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lt7fAH0s7QYC&pg=PA134|accessdate=20 August 2013|date=May 2008|publisher=Lawyers & Judges Publishing Company|isbn=978-1-933264-54-7|pages=134}}</ref>
It is to be noted that in principle alternating occlusion may interfere with normal visual input. Strictly speaking, alternating occlusion is a form of visual deprivation and as such may have negative effects during a [[critical period]] of development. Experiments on kittens that were published 1965 by Hubel and Wiesel showed that continuously submitting kittens at a young age to a protocol under which the eyes were alternatingly occluded on a day-by-day basis over a prolonged period of time led to changes in the visual cortex, in particular a disruption in cellular connections that would normally enable binocular vision.<ref>{{cite news|author1=D.H. Hubel|author2=T.N. Wiesel|title=Binocular interaction in striate cortex of kittens reared with artificial squint|journal=Journal of Neurophysiology|volume=28|number=6|year=1965|pages=1041–1059}}</ref> Experiments with rearing young kittens under rapidly alternating monocular occlusion using constantly-worn electronic goggles showed that cortical binocularity was reduced if the flicker rate was 2 Hz or lower, and that binocularity developed normally if it was 2.5 or 3 or 5 Hz.<ref>{{cite news|author1=L. Altmann L|author2=H.J. Luhmann|author3=J.M. Greuel|author4=W. Singer|title=Functional and neuronal binocularity in kittens raised with rapidly alternating monocular occlusion|journal=Journal of Neurophysiology|date=November 1987|volume=58|number=5|pages=965–980|pmid=3694253}}</ref>

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Asomatognosia | synonym = | image = | width = | alt = | caption = | pronounce = | field = <!-- from Wikidata, can be overwritten --> | symptoms = | onset = | duration = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | frequency = | deaths = }}'''Asomatognosia''' is a [[neurological disorder]] characterized as loss of recognition or awareness of part of the body.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1001/archneur.63.7.1022| title = Neural Mechanisms of Embodiment| journal = Archives of Neurology| volume = 63| issue = 7| pages = 1022| year = 2006| last1 = Arzy | first1 = S. | last2 = Overney | first2 = L. S. | last3 = Landis | first3 = T. | last4 = Blanke | first4 = O. }}</ref><ref name="Vallar">Vallar, G. & Ronchi, R. (2009). Somatoparaphrenia: a body delusion. A review of the neuropsychological literature. Experimental Brain Research, 192:3, 533-551</ref> The failure to acknowledge, for example, a limb, may be expressed verbally or as a pattern of neglect. The limb may also be attributed to another person, a delusion known as [[somatoparaphrenia]]. However, they can be shown their limb and this error is temporarily corrected.<ref name="Feinberg">Feinberg, T., Venneri, A., Simone, A.M., et al. (2010). The neuroanatomy of asomatognosia and somatoparaphrenia. Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry, 81, 276-281</ref><ref>Bottini, Gabriella; Bisiach, Edoardo; Sterzi, Roberto; Vallar, Giuseppe (2002): “Feeling touches in someone else's hand.” NeuroReport 13 (2), 249–252.</ref> Some authors have focused on the prevalence of [[hemispatial neglect]] in such patients.<ref name="Larner2010">{{cite book|author=A.J. Larner|title=A Dictionary of Neurological Signs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mY-6eweiQm8C&pg=PA43|date=12 November 2010|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4419-7095-4|page=43}}</ref>
== Introduction == Asomatognosia is the inability to feel, recognize, or be conscious of one’s own specific body parts and/or bodily conditions (Whishaw, 2015). Generally, asomatognosia often arises from damage to the right parietal lobe (Whishaw, 2015). Evidence indicates that damage to the right hemisphere often results from a stroke or pre-existing hemispatial neglect, or inattention to the left visual field (Antoniello, 2016) (Keenan, 2004). Individuals who suffer from somatoparaphrenia, a specific form of asomatognosia, ignore or deny ownership of a body part contralateral to the brain lesion (Feinberg, 1990). Although this condition can affect one or both sides of the body, most patients exhibit the inability to recognize limbs/body parts (i.e. arm, leg, head, breast) on the left side of their body as their own (Keenan, 2004). While individuals with asomatognosia typically suffer large lesions across several temporoparietal sectors, those with somatoparaphrenia also suffer lesions in the right medial and orbitofrontal regions of the brain (Feinberg 2010).
== Patient Cases == In most commonly observed instances, individuals with this condition fail to recognize and sense their left arm after suffering lesions to the right hemisphere (Keenan, 2004). In one specific instance, a patient suffering from asomatognosia tried to throw her own left arm into a garbage can because she believed it was her husband’s arm repeatedly falling on her and disrupting her sleep (Keenan, 2004). Even when patients are told that the body part belongs to them, many will deny the reality and remain firm in their belief that it is not a part of them. There is an interesting case in which a patient with severe asomatognosia had the ability to use his right hand to trace his paralyzed left arm to his own left shoulder, but still failed to acknowledge that the left arm belonged to him (Keenan, 2004). Overall, there is an interesting phenomenon in which individuals will claim that the body part belongs to someone of the opposite gender within their family. For example, women with asomatognosia tend to claim that their left arm belongs to a man (i.e. their husband) while men claim their arm belongs to a woman, such as his daughter or wife. There are also exists patients that treat the arm as a child or small animal. (Keenan, 2004)
== Related Conditions == In addition to instances of asomatognosia in which patients deny ownership of a specific part, this condition is also associated with the following: anosognosia (unawareness or denial of illness), anosodiaphoria (indifference to illness), autopagnosia (inability to localize and name body parts), and asymbolia for pain (absence of typical reactions to pain). Out of these varieties of asomatognosia, autopagnosia is the only one in which an individual struggles to recognize the right side of their body due to lesions in the left parietal cortex (Whishaw, 2015).
See also
* [[Anosognosia]], a condition in which a person is unaware or in denial of an illness.

The '''California Homemade Food Act''' is a law that legalizes the manufacture and sale of certain homemade food products.<ref name="Camp">{{cite web | last = Camp| first = Scott| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Cottage Food Law Explained| work = | publisher = Santa Barbara Independent, inc.| date = 17 March 2013| url = http://www.independent.com/news/2013/mar/17/cottage-food-law-explained/| format = | doi = | accessdate = 13 April 2013}}</ref> Introduced as bill AB1616, the California Homemade Food Act was signed by Governor [[Jerry Brown]] and became law effective January 1, 2013.
Prior to the enactment of the California Homemade Food Act, entrepreneurs were subjected to the same regulations as commercial restaurants and bakeries. [[Food safety]] laws forced owners to have to rent part of a retail [[kitchen]] and prepare all of their products there.<ref name="Duggan">{{cite web | last = Duggan| first = Tara| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Selling home-baked goods now legalized| work = San Francisco Chronicle| publisher = Hearst Communications Inc.| date = 12 January 2013| url = http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Selling-home-baked-goods-now-legalized-4189891.php#page-1| format = | doi = | accessdate = 13 April 2013 }}</ref> Rental costs, along with the costs of complying with other health regulations, made it difficult for small-scale homemade food businesses to turn a profit. This law allows home cooks to run enterprises, termed a Cottage Food Operation or a "CFO", that manufacture "low-risk" foods from within the individual's home.<ref name="FAQ">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =California Homemade Food Act Frequently Asked Questions| work =| publisher =California Conference of Directors of Environmental Health| date =1 November 2012| url =http://www.ccdeh.com/document/doc_view/1015-ab-1616-frequently-asked-questions-updated-2012-11-01| format =| doi =| accessdate =13 April 2013| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20131029200553/http://www.ccdeh.com/document/doc_view/1015-ab-1616-frequently-asked-questions-updated-2012-11-01#| archive-date =2013-10-29| dead-url =yes| df =}}</ref> These "low-risk" foods must be less susceptible to [[Meat spoilage|bacterial growth]] that could cause [[Foodborne illness|food poisoning]]; they must be able to stay fresh without needing [[refrigeration]]. For this reason, Cottage Food Operations are still barred from selling [[dairy product]]s and [[meat]].<ref name="McEwen">{{cite journal | last = McEwen| first = Stephen A. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The California Homemade Food Act: Cottage Food Operations Arrive In California | work = Public Law Update| volume = 7| issue = 1| pages = 2–8| publisher = Burke, Williams, and Sorenson, LLP| location = | date = | language = | url = http://www.bwslaw.com/tasks/sites/bwslaw/assets/Image/January%202013%20Public%20Law%20Update.pdf| jstor = | issn = | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate = 13 April 2013 }}</ref><ref name="Gansky">{{cite web | last = Gansky| first = Lisa| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = New California law kickstarts home-based food businesses| work = | publisher = The Christian Science Monitor| date = 28 September 2012| url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Making-a-difference/Change-Agent/2012/0928/New-California-law-kickstarts-home-based-food-businesses| format = | doi = | accessdate = 13 April 2013 }}</ref> The California Department of Public Health has compiled a list of "low-risk" foods, which are approved for a CFO to produce, prepare, package, and peddle to customers out of their "private home". A CFO is limited to producing and selling foods found on this [http://www.cdph.ca.gov/programs/Documents/fdbCFOfoodslist.pdf '''list''']. A "private home" can be either owned or rented by the operator of the CFO, and thus includes both houses and apartments.
The California Homemade Food Act also relaxes many [[zoning]] restrictions for CFOs, since traditional bakeries would not be allowed to operate out of a residential area. Nevertheless, Cottage Food Operations will still have to apply for a permit from the County Department of Health and follow numerous other regulations set under the law.<ref name="McEwen"/><ref name="Hallock">{{cite web | last = Hallock| first = Betty| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Jam on: California Homemade Food Act goes into effect in January| work = | publisher = Los Angeles Times| date = 10 December 2012| url = http://articles.latimes.com/2012/dec/10/news/la-dd-california-homemade-food-act-goes-into-effect-in-january-20121210| format = | doi = | accessdate = 13 April 2013 }}</ref>
==Legislative history==
On February 8, 2012, [[Mike Gatto]], the assemblyman for the [[California's 43rd State Assembly district|43rd district]], introduced the California Homemade Food Act on to the floor of the [[California State Assembly]].<ref name="NewLegInfo">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = AB-1616 Food safety: cottage food operations. (2011-2012)| work = California Legislative Information| publisher = | date = | url = http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201120120AB1616&search_keywords=| format = | doi = | accessdate = 11 May 2013 }}</ref> Gatto authored the bill in response to the closure of a cottage food business of one of his constituents. Mark Stambler's<ref>[http://www.rootsimple.com/2012/10/california-homemade-food-act-signed-into-law/ California Homemade Food Act Signed Into Law! - Root Simple (Erik Knutzen)]</ref> homemade bread business was deemed in violation of food safety laws by the [[Los Angeles County Department of Public Health]] and forced to shut down. Gatto's bill sought a state-wide standardization of food safety laws for cottage food industries while curbing regulations Gatto called "paradoxical and nonsensical." <ref name="GT">{{cite web | last = Short| first = April M.| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Homemade in California| work = | publisher = Santa Cruz Good Times| date = 3 April 2012| url = http://www.gtweekly.com/index.php/santa-cruz-news/santa-cruz-environmental-news/3656-homemade-in-california.html| doi = | accessdate = 11 May 2013 }}</ref><ref name="Mantle">{{cite web | last = Mantle| first = Larry| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = California bill would give local food producers legitimacy| work = AirTalk| publisher = Southern California Public Radio| date = 1 June 2012| url = http://www.scpr.org/programs/airtalk/2012/06/01/26714/stambler-bill/| format = | doi = | accessdate = 11 May 2013 }}</ref>
The [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] passed the bill on May 29, 2012, by a vote of 56-19 with 5 members not voting. The [[California State Senate|Senate]] passed the bill along with several amendments on August 30, 2012, by the unanimous vote of the 34 senators present (6 senators did not vote). The Senate amendments required the bill to return to the Assembly, which approved the amended version on August 30 by a vote of 60-16 with 4 Assemblymen not voting. No Assembly members who supported the bill in the first vote opposed the bill in the second vote. There were two assembly members, [[Connie Conway]] and [[Jim Nielsen]], who voted against the bill in the first vote but subsequently voted for the bill in the second vote.<ref name="NewLegInfo"/>
Governor [[Jerry Brown]] signed the California Homemade Food Act into law on September 21, 2012. Brown praised the bill as a measure to facilitate hiring by California businesses.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Governor Brown Signs Legislation To Bolster Business| work = | publisher = Office of Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr.| date = 21 September 2012| url = http://gov.ca.gov/news.php?id=17741| format = | doi = | accessdate = 11 May 2013 }}</ref>

Chen Kesi | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = {{nowrap|[[Time 100|''Time'' 100]] (2006)
[[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] (2007)}} | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} {{chinese-name|[[Chen (surname)|Chen]]}} {{Chinese|s=陈光诚|t=陳光誠|p=Chén Guāngchéng|mi={{IPAc-cmn|ch|en|2|-|g|uang|1|ch|eng|2}}}} '''Chen Guangcheng''' (born 12 November 1971) is a Chinese [[civil rights]] activist who has worked on human rights issues in rural areas of the [[People's Republic of China]]. Blind from an early age and self-taught in the law, Chen is frequently described as a "[[barefoot lawyer]]" who advocates for [[women's rights]], [[land rights]], and the welfare of the poor. He is best known for accusing people of abuses in official family-planning practices, often involving claims of violence and [[forced abortion]]s. In 2005, Chen gained international recognition for organising a landmark [[class-action lawsuit]] against authorities in [[Linyi]], [[Shandong province]], for the excessive enforcement of the [[one-child policy]]. As a result of this lawsuit, Chen was placed under house arrest from September 2005 to March 2006, with a formal arrest in June 2006. On 24 August 2006, Chen was sentenced to four years and three months for "damaging property and organising a mob to disturb traffic." He was released from prison in 2010 after serving his full sentence, but remained under [[house arrest]] or "[[soft detention]]" at his home in [[Dongshigu]] Village. Chen and his wife were reportedly beaten shortly after a human rights group released a video of their home under intense police surveillance in February 2011. Chen's case received sustained international attention, with the [[U.S. State Department]], the [[British Foreign Secretary]], [[Human Rights Watch]], and [[Amnesty International]] issuing appeals for his release; the latter group designated him a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Chen is a 2007 laureate of the [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] and in 2006 was named to the [[Time 100|''Time'' 100]]. In April 2012, Chen escaped his house arrest and fled to the [[Embassy of the United States, Beijing|U.S. Embassy in Beijing]]. After negotiations with the Chinese government, he left the embassy for medical treatment in early May 2012, and it was reported that China would consider allowing him to travel to the United States to study. On 19 May 2012, Chen, his wife, and his two children were granted [[U.S. Visa|U.S. visas]] and departed Beijing for [[New York City]]. In October 2013, Chen accepted a position with the conservative research group [[Witherspoon Institute]], and a position at the [[Catholic University of America]].{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/03/world/americas/chinese-activist-joins-conservative-research-group.html | work=The New York Times | first=Andrew | last=Jacobs | title=Chinese Activist Joins Conservative Research Group | date=2 October 2013}} == Early life and family == Chen is the youngest of five brothers of a peasant family from the village of [[Dongshigu]], [[Yinan County]], [[Shandong Province]], approximately {{convert|200|km|mi}} from the city of [[Jinan]]. When Chen was about six months old, he [[Blindness|lost his sight]] due to a fever that destroyed his optical nerves.{{cite web|url=http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2012/jun/26/chen-guangcheng-interview/ |title='Pressure for Change is at the Grassroots': An Interview with Chen Guangcheng |author=Ian Johnson |date=20 June 2012 |work=New York Review of Books |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CI9mMFCf?url=http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2012/jun/26/chen-guangcheng-interview/ |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In an interview for the ''[[New York Review of Books]]'', Chen said that although his family did not identify with an organized religion, his upbringing was informed by a "traditional belief in virtue that’s present in Chinese culture—that might have some Buddhist content, but not necessarily that one believes in Buddhism." His village was poor, with many families living at a subsistence level. "When I went to school I’d be happy if I just got enough to eat," he recalled. Chen's father worked as an instructor at a Communist Party school, earning the equivalent of about $60 annually. When Chen was a child, his father would read literary works aloud to him, and reportedly helped impart to his son an appreciation of the values of democracy and freedom. In 1991, Chen's father gave him a copy of "The Law Protecting the Disabled," which elaborated on the legal rights and protections in place for disabled persons in the PRC. In 1989, at the age of 18, Chen began attending school as a grade one student at the Elementary School for the Blind in [[Linyi]] city. In 1994, he enrolled at the [[Qingdao]] High School for the Blind, where he studied until 1998.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-17866176 |title=China's blind activist Chen Guangcheng |date=19 May 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=18 November 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIDm1QVy?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-17866176 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} He had already begun developing an interest in law, and would often ask his brothers to read legal texts to him. He earned a position at the [[Nanjing University of Traditional Chinese Medicine]] in 1998 but because his family was poor, they had to borrow $340 to cover tuition costs. They still fell short of the required $400 and university authorities reportedly had to be pleaded with before allowing Chen to enroll.Lijia MacLeod. "Scholastic sticker shock: Tuition increases put college out of most families' reach". ''The Washington Times''. 6 October 2000. He studied in Nanjing from 1998 to 2001, specializing in [[acupuncture]] and massage—the only programs available to the blind. Chen also audited legal courses, gaining a sufficient understanding of the law to allow him to aid his fellow villagers when they sought his assistance.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/08/26/AR2005082601756.html |title=Who Controls the Family? |author=Philip P. Pan |date=27 August 2005 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIGaETRE?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/08/26/AR2005082601756.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2002/03/03/barefoot-lawyers.html |title=Barefoot Lawyers |author=Melinda Liu |date=3 March 2002 |work=Newsweek |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIGarRVh?url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2002/03/03/barefoot-lawyers.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} After graduation he returned to his home region and found a job as a [[Massage|masseur]] in the hospital of [[Yinan County]].{{cite web|url=http://www.my1510.cn/article.php?id=2cf7ced4357139bb |script-title=zh:陈光诚：不平凡的基层维权先锋 |language=Chinese |publisher=My1510.cn |date=24 October 2008 |accessdate=16 December 2011 |archivedate=3 March 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303001726/http://www.my1510.cn/article.php?id=2cf7ced4357139bb |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Chen met his wife, Yuan Weijing, in 2001, after listening to a radio talk show. Yuan had called into the show to discuss her difficulties in landing a job after graduating from the foreign language department of Shandong's Chemistry Institute. Chen, who listened to the program, later contacted Yuan and relayed his own story of hardship as a blind man living on just 400 Yuan per year. Yuan was moved by the exchange, and later that year, she traveled to Chen's village to meet him. The couple eloped in 2003. Their son, Chen Kerui, was born later that year. In 2005 they had a second child—a daughter named Chen Kesi—in violation of China's one-child policy.{{cite web|url=http://behindthewall.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/05/04/11540235-why-did-blind-activist-chen-guangcheng-anger-chinese-authorities?lite |title=Why did blind activist Chen Guangcheng anger Chinese authorities? |date=4 May 2012 |publisher=NBC News |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=12 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512032235/http://behindthewall.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/05/04/11540235-why-did-blind-activist-chen-guangcheng-anger-chinese-authorities?lite |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/05/21/chen-guangcheng-s-new-life-in-america-a-day-in-greenwich-village.html |title=Chen Guangcheng's New Life in America: A Day in Greenwich Village |date=21 May 2012 |work=Newsweek |author=Melinda Liu |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIKQ3zLW?url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/05/21/chen-guangcheng-s-new-life-in-america-a-day-in-greenwich-village.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Yuan, who had been working as an English teacher at the time of the marriage, left her job in 2003 in order to assist her husband in his legal work. == Activism == {{Weiquan Lawyers}} Chen first [[petitioning (China)|petitioned]] authorities in 1996, when he traveled to Beijing to complain about taxes that were incorrectly being levied on his family (people with disabilities, such as Chen, are supposed to be exempt from taxation and fees). The complaint was successful, and Chen began petitioning for other individuals with disabilities.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/20/world/asia/20blind.html?_r=1 |title=Advocate for China's Weak Crosses the Powerful |author=Joseph Kahn |date=20 July 2006 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIGPBkXQ?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/20/world/asia/20blind.html?_r=2&adxnnl=1&adxnnlx=1353337412-PfxI8EyqxcbcpI+j9LJ+RQ&# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} With funding from a British foundation, Chen became an outspoken activist for disability rights within the China Law Society. His reputation as a disability rights advocate was solidified when agreed to advocate for an elderly blind couple whose grandchildren suffered from paralysis. The family had been paying all of the regular taxes and fees, but Chen believed that, under the law, the family should have received government assistance and exemption from taxation. When the case went to court, blind citizens from surrounding counties were in attendance as a show of solidarity. The case was successful, and the outcome became well-known. In 1997, the leaders of Chen's village began implementing a land use plan that gave authorities control over 60 percent of land, which they then rented out at high cost to the villages. The plan, known as the "two-field system," was a major source of enrichment for the local government. While studying in Nanjing the following year, however, Chen learned that the program was illegal, and he petitioned central authorities in Beijing to end the system, thereby irritating local officials.{{cite web |url=http://hrichina.org/sites/default/files/oldsite/PDFs/CRF.3.2006/CRF-2006-3_Chen-Guangcheng.pdf |title=Chen Guangcheng and Wen Jiabao: Power vs. Human Rights |author=Zhang Yaojie |year=2006 |publisher=Human Rights in China |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CI9q5tRw?url=http://hrichina.org/sites/default/files/oldsite/PDFs/CRF.3.2006/CRF-2006-3_Chen-Guangcheng.pdf# |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} In 2000, Chen returned from his studies in Nanjing to his village of Dongshigu in an effort to confront environmental pollution.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-5116843.html |title=Frontline Shandong: A story harder to swallow than crispy scorpions |date=4 October 2000 |author=Calum and Lijia MacLeod |work=The Independent |accessdate=10 August 2012}} (subscription required) A paper mill constructed in 1988 had been dumping toxic wastewater into the Meng river, destroying crops and harming wildlife. The chemicals also reportedly caused skin and digestive problems among villagers living downstream from the mill. Chen organized villagers in his hometown and 78 other villages to petition against the mill. The effort was successful, and resulted in the suspension of the paper mill. In addition, Chen contacted the British embassy in Beijing, informing them of the situation and requesting funding for a well to supply clean water to locals. The British government responded by providing £15,000 towards a deep water well, irrigation systems and water pipelines.Calum and Lijia Macleod (22 October 2000). "Chinese peasants fight for clean water". United Press International. In March 2004, more than 300 residents from Chen's village of Dongshigu filed a petition to the village government demanding that they release the village accounts—which hadn't been made public for over ten years—and address the issue of [[Forced eviction in China|illegal land requisitions]]. When village authorities failed to respond, villagers escalated their appeals to the township, county and municipal governments, still without response. Village authorities then began to publicly threaten villagers. In November 2004, Chen acted on behalf of villagers to file a lawsuit in the Qi'nan County Court against the local [[Public Security Bureau]] for negligence. The case was accepted, and proceedings began in early 2005. In 2005, Chen spent several months surveying residents of [[Shandong]] Province, collecting accounts of forced, late-term abortions and forced sterilization of women who stood in violation of China’s one-child policy. His survey was based in Linyi and included surrounding rural suburbs. Chen later recalled that his survey would have been significantly larger in scope were he not limited by a lack of financial resources. Though Chinese central authorities have sought to curb the coercive enforcement of the one-child policy since 1990 by replacing measures such as forced abortions and sterilizations with a system of financial incentives and fines, Chen found that coercive practices remained widespread, and he documented numerous cases of abuse. One of the women he interviewed in Maxiagou village, 36-year-old Feng Zhongxia, said that local officials detained and beat her relatives, and indicated they would not be released until she turned herself in and submitted to a forced abortion. She said she was later subjected to forced sterilization. Chen also solicited the help of prominent legal scholar [[Teng Biao]], who conducted his own interviews in Linyi. Teng and Chen later released a report claiming that an estimated 130,000 residents in the city had been forced into 'study sessions' for refusing abortions or violating the one-child policy; residents would be held for days or weeks in the study sessions, and were allegedly beaten."Scholar's report details 'violent birth control scheme' in China". Kyodo News Service. 5 September 2005. In 2005, Chen filed a [[class-action lawsuit]] on behalf of women from Linyi against the city's family planning staff.{{cite news|title=Chinese to Prosecute Peasant Who Resisted One-Child Policy |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/07/AR2006070701510.html |date=8 July 2006 |author=Philip P. Pan |accessdate=28 April 2010 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIGl61U0?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/07/AR2006070701510.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} And in June, he traveled to Beijing to file the complaint and meet with foreign reporters to publicize the case.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1975813_1975847_1976744,00.html |title=TIME 100: The People Who Shape Our World |work=Time |date=30 April 2006 |author=Hannah Beech |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIGQnAaA?url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1975813_1975847_1976744,00.html# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} Although there had been prior instances of Chinese citizens filing complaints about abuses under the one-child policy, Chen’s initiative was the first class-action lawsuit to challenge its implementation. Although the suit he filed was rejected, the case garnered international media attention. Responding to questions about Chen’s allegation, a senior official with the [[National Population and Family Planning Commission]] told the ''Washington Post'' that the practice of forced abortions and sterilizations was “definitely illegal,” and indicated that the complaints were being investigated. “If the Linyi complaints are true, or even partly true, it's because local officials do not understand the new demands of the Chinese leadership regarding family planning work,” said the official. In September 2005, the Commission announced that several Linyi officials had been detained.{{cite web|date=19 July 2006 |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2006/07/18/chronology-chen-guangchengs-case |title=Chronology of Chen Guangcheng's Case |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=26 July 2006 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIGuQdOu?url=http://www.hrw.org/news/2006/07/18/chronology-chen-guangchengs-case |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} But local authorities in Linyi retaliated against Chen, placing him under house arrest in September 2005 and embarking on a campaign to undermine his reputation; the Linyi officials portrayed him as working for "foreign anti-China forces", pointing out that he had received foreign funding for his advocacy on behalf of the disabled. == Detention and trial == On 7 September 2005, while Chen was in Beijing to publicize his class action lawsuit against the Linyi city family planning staff, he was reportedly abducted by security agents from Linyi and held for 38 hours. Recounting the incident to foreign journalists, Chen said that authorities threatened to levy criminal charges against him for providing state secrets or intelligence to foreign organizations.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china_kidnapping-20050908.html |title=Blind Chinese Activist Describes 38-Hour Kidnapping by Shandong Officials |author=Lillian Cheung and Ding Xiao |date=8 September 2005 |publisher=Radio Free Asia |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIH1TZUd?url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china_kidnapping-20050908.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} After Chen refused negotiations with local officials to cease his activism, Linyi authorities placed him under effective house arrest beginning in September 2005. When he attempted to escape in October, he was beaten. [[Xinhua]], the news agency of the Chinese government, stated that on 5 February 2006, Chen instigated others "to damage and smash cars belonging to the Shuanghou Police Station and the town government" as well as attack local government officials.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-08/25/content_673807.htm |title=Blind mob organizer sentenced to imprisonment |date=25 August 2006 |work=China Daily |agency=Xinhua |accessdate=3 January 2013 |archivedate=3 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DOw4OJsO?url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2006-08/25/content_673807.htm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' reported that witnesses to Chen's protest disputed the government's version of events,{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1376215,00.html |title=China: China: First Person: Blind Justice |author=Hannah Beech |date=27 August 2006 |work=Time |accessdate=3 January 2013 |archivedate=3 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DOw6onod?url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1376215,00.html# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} and his lawyers argued that it was unlikely he could have committed the crimes due to his constant surveillance by police.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/25/world/asia/25zhaobox.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |title=China Gives Times Researcher 3 Years |author=Jim Yardley and Joseph Kahn |date=25 August 2006 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=3 January 2013 |archivedate=3 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DOw8BOYj?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/25/world/asia/25zhaobox.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} Chen was removed from his house in March 2006 and was formally detained in June 2006 by Yinan county officials. He was scheduled to stand trial on 17 July 2006 on charges of destruction of property and assembling a crowd to disrupt traffic, but this was delayed at the request of the prosecution.{{cite news|title=Scuffles at China activist trial |publisher=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/5197340.stm |date=20 July 2006 |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIH2PmWF?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5197340.stm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} According to [[Radio Free Asia]] and [[Chinese Human Rights Defenders]], the prosecution delayed the trial because a crowd of Chen supporters gathered outside the courthouse. With only a few days' notice, authorities rescheduled Chen's trial for 18 August 2006. On the eve of his trial, all three of his lawyers, including [[Xu Zhiyong]] of the [[Yitong Law Firm]], were detained by Yinan police; two were released after being questioned.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/5262748.stm |date=18 August 2006 |title=China abortion activist on trial |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=3 July 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIH2sg5u?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5262748.stm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Neither Chen's lawyers nor his wife were allowed in the courtroom for the trial. Authorities appointed their own public defender for Chen just before the trial began.{{cite book|title="A Great Danger for Lawyers": New Regulatory Curbs on Lawyers Representing Protesters|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ubDxjxQLr98C&pg=PA24|accessdate=28 July 2012|year=2006|publisher=Human Rights Watch|pages=24–|id=GGKEY:77PX03QJRF0}} The trial lasted only two hours. On 24 August 2006, Chen was sentenced to four years and three months for "damaging property and organizing a mob to disturb traffic".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5281440.stm |title=China abortion activist sentenced |publisher=BBC News |date=24 August 2006 |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHDB10w?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5281440.stm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} As a result of Chen's trial, British Foreign Secretary [[Margaret Beckett]] selected his case for the cover of the British government's 2006 human rights report, stating concern over the handling of Chen's case and calling for the Chinese government "to prove its commitment to building rule of law."{{cite web|url=http://www.gov-news.org/gov/uk/news/foreign_secretary_welcomes_chinese_human/57513.html |title=Foreign Secretary welcomes Chinese human rights defender's sentence being overturned |date=2 November 2006 |publisher=gov-news.org |accessdate=28 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHG2udz?url=http://www.gov-news.org/gov/uk/news/foreign_secretary_welcomes_chinese_human/57513.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/chinese/simp/hi/newsid_6110000/newsid_6111400/6111446.stm |script-title=zh:英外相促请公正处理陈光诚二审 |language=Chinese |date=2 November 2006 |publisher=BBC Chinese |accessdate=28 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHHmNi8?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/chinese/simp/hi/newsid_6110000/newsid_6111400/6111446.stm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} A columnist for ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' also criticized the verdict, writing that "Even assuming [Chen] did damage 'doors and windows,' as well as cars, and interrupt traffic for three hours, it is difficult to argue a four-year prison sentence is somehow proportionate to the offence."{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/commentary/rights-fight-here-to-stay-in-china/article731567/ |title=Rights fight here to stay in China |author=Frank Ching |date=29 August 2006 |work=The Globe and Mail |accessdate=3 January 2013 |location=Toronto}} On 30 November 2006, Yinan County court upheld Chen's sentence,{{cite news|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/latestnews/print/42782.htm |title=Chinese court upholds blind activist's sentence of more than four years in prison |date=1 December 2006 |work=China Post |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=27 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHMSOjq?url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/latestnews/print/42782.htm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} and on 12 January 2007, the Linyi Intermediate Court in Shandong Province rejected his final appeal. The same court had overturned his original conviction in December 2006, citing lack of evidence. However, Chen was convicted in a second trial on identical charges and given an identical sentence by the Yinan court.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/13/world/asia/13beijing.html |title=Chinese Court Upholds Conviction of Peasants' Advocate |accessdate=10 August 2012 |date=12 January 2007 |author=Joseph Kahn |work=The New York Times |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHMtFhI?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/13/world/asia/13beijing.html?_r=0# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} Following the trial, [[Amnesty International]] declared him to be a [[prisoner of conscience]], "jailed solely for his peaceful activities in defence of human rights".{{cite web |url=http://asiapacific.amnesty.org/apro/APROweb.nsf/c6ed44235bceff2248256e54001d315b/7cd64e5a4530c06b48257310002f0a4a!OpenDocument |title=China: jailed HRD lawyer beaten, goes on hunger strike |publisher=Amnesty International |accessdate=18 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216152319/http://asiapacific.amnesty.org/apro/aproweb.nsf/c6ed44235bceff2248256e54001d315b/7cd64e5a4530c06b48257310002f0a4a%21OpenDocument |archivedate=16 February 2008 |df=dmy }} == House arrest == After his release from prison in 2010, Chen was placed under [[house arrest]] against Chinese law, and was closely monitored by security forces. Legally, he was proclaimed by the government to be a free man, but in reality the local government offered no explanation for the hundreds of unidentified agents monitoring his house and preventing visitors or escape. The national propaganda organ, the ''[[Global Times]]'', expressed confusion over the issue, and suggested that the local government may not know how to handle it, but no disciplinary action was taken at the national level.{{cite web|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/NEWS/tabid/99/ID/678927/Dont-turn-a-village-into-a-pressure-cooker.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403221739/http://www.globaltimes.cn/NEWS/tabid/99/ID/678927/Dont-turn-a-village-into-a-pressure-cooker.aspx |archivedate=3 April 2013 |df=dmy }} He and his wife attempted to communicate with the outside world via video tape and letters. Letters described beatings Chen and his wife were subjected to, seizure of documents and communication devices, cutting off of electric power to their residence, and placing of metal sheets over the windows of their house.{{cite news |title=Chinese Officials Beat Activist and His Wife, Group Says |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/world/asia/18china.html |accessdate=18 June 2011 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=17 June 2011 |author=Ian Johnson |author2=Jonathan Ansfield |quote=bundled into a blanket and repeatedly kicked |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHXXHH9?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/world/asia/18china.html?_r=0# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} Harassment of Chen's family continued throughout his house arrest, and extended to Chen's six-year-old daughter, who was briefly banned from attending school and had her toys confiscated by guards, and to Chen's mother, who was harassed while working in the fields.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/apr/27/chen-guangcheng-china-lockdown?intcmp=239 |title=Chen Guangcheng: how China tried to lock down a blind man |author=Tania Branigan |date=27 April 2012 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=27 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHXtGuC?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/apr/27/chen-guangcheng-china-lockdown?intcmp=239 |deadurl=no |location=London |df=dmy-all }} Authorities reportedly told Chen that they had spent 60 million yuan ($9.5 million) to keep him under house arrest.Chris Buckley (30 April 2012). [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/30/us-china-politics-security-idUSBRE83T06J20120430 "China security chief down but not out after blind dissident's escape"]. Reuters. [https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHYFrSo?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/30/us-china-politics-security-idUSBRE83T06J20120430 Archived] from the original on 19 November 2012. Retrieved 10 August 2012. In 2011, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that a number of supporters and admirers had attempted to penetrate the security monitoring Chen's home, but were unsuccessful. In some instances, his supporters were pummeled, beaten, or robbed by security agents.Andrew Jacobs (18 October 2011), [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/19/world/asia/despite-violence-chinese-dissidents-emboldened-supporters-stream-to-see-him.html?_r=1&ref=world "Despite Violence, Chinese Dissidents' Emboldened Supporters Stream to See Him"]. ''The New York Times''. [https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHnxKcl?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/19/world/asia/despite-violence-chinese-dissidents-emboldened-supporters-stream-to-see-him.html?_r=2&ref=world& Archived] from the original on 19 November 2012. Retrieved 10 August 2012. news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jsPMWMLFWn0qnAbT8AgNP8_Dlabw?docId=CNG.f7fee1d3e211a5423a39162aa46fc669.01 |title=US lawmaker seeks to visit blind China rights lawyer }} U.S. Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] described the U.S. government as "alarmed" by Chen's continued detention and called on China "to embrace a different path".{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iofJbGefybreI5bhuMjyIsqdFnQA?docId=CNG.49ace90e35aac4b84d990f3beef83a13.81 |title=Clinton presses China on Tibet, blind lawyer
