[[Christian Bale]] attempted to visit Chen along with a [[CNN]] crew, but was punched, shoved, and denied access by Chinese security guards. Bale later stated that he had wanted "to meet the man, shake his hand and say what an inspiration he is."{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-16215416 |title=Christian Bale barred from visiting China activist Chen |date=16 December 2011 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=27 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHxlbQ1?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-16215416 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news|author=Malcolm Moore |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8960076/Christian-Bale-manhandled-while-trying-to-visit-Chinese-activist.html |title=Christian Bale manhandled while trying to visit Chinese activist |work=The Telegraph |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHy8ZtY?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8960076/Christian-Bale-manhandled-while-trying-to-visit-Chinese-activist.html |deadurl=no |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=10 August 2012 |location=London |df=dmy }} Video footage also showed Bale and the CNN crew having stones thrown at them, and being pursued in their minivan for more than 40 minutes.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/12/15/world/asia/china-bale-activist/index.html?hpt=hp_c2 |title='Batman' star Bale punched, stopped from visiting blind Chinese activist |archivedate=27 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427202900/http://edition.cnn.com/2011/12/15/world/asia/china-bale-activist/index.html?hpt=hp_c2 |deadurl=no |date=17 December 2011 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=27 April 2012 |df=dmy }} == Escape and emigration == [[File:Kurt Campbell with Chen Guangcheng at US Embassy May 1, 2012.jpg|thumb|Chen (left) with [[Gary Locke]] (center) and [[Kurt M. Campbell]] (right) at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing on 1 May 2012]] On 22 April 2012, Chen escaped from house arrest.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2012/04/27/151522792/blind-activist-flees-house-arrest-in-china |title=Blind Activist Flees House Arrest In China |author=Mark Memmott |date=27 April 2012 |publisher=NPR |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CII8RoyJ?url=http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2012/04/27/151522792/blind-activist-flees-house-arrest-in-china |deadurl=no |accessdate=27 April 2012 |df=dmy }} Chen's fellow activist [[Hu Jia (activist)|Hu Jia]] stated that Chen had been planning escape for a long time, and had previously attempted to dig a tunnel for escape.{{cite news|author=Yuwen Wu |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17865465 |title=China dissident Chen Guangcheng escapes house arrest |publisher=BBC News |date=27 April 2012 |accessdate=1 July 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CII8mbjI?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17865465 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In the weeks leading up to his escape, Chen gave his guards the impression that he was ill in bed, and stopped appearing outside the house, which allowed him several days before any absence would be discovered. Under cover of darkness and with the help of his wife, Chen climbed over the wall around his house, breaking his foot in the process.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-18113021 |title=The Great Escape |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIIMqoxr?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-18113021 |deadurl=no |date=18 May 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=19 May 2012 |df=dmy }} When he came upon the [[Meng River]], he found it to be guarded, but crossed anyway and was not stopped; he later stated that he believed the guards had been asleep. Though he recollected his immediate surroundings from his childhood explorations, he eventually passed into less familiar territory; he later told his supporters that he fell more than 200 times during his escape. Communicating with a network of activists via a cell phone, he reached a pre-determined rendezvous point where [[He ‘Pearl' Peirong|He Peirong]], an English teacher and activist, was waiting for him.{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Running-blind-Chinese-activist-s-dramatic-escape-3521796.php#page-1 |title=Running blind: Chinese activist's dramatic escape |author=Alexa Oleson |date=30 April 2012 |work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer |archivedate=1 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501173032/http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Running-blind-Chinese-activist-s-dramatic-escape-3521796.php |deadurl=no |accessdate=29 April 2012}} A chain of human rights activists then escorted him to Beijing. Several of the activists reported to be involved were detained or disappeared in the days following the announcement of Chen's escape.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17885372 |title=Chen Guangcheng's escape sparks China round-up |publisher=BBC News |date=29 April 2012 |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIINrdq8?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17885372 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Chen was given refuge at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, though the Embassy initially declined to confirm or deny reports that they were sheltering him.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17877005 |title=China dissident Chen Guangcheng 'in US embassy' |date=27 April 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=27 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CII98JAg?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17877005 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The Embassy later said they had accepted Chen on humanitarian grounds and offered him medical assistance.{{cite news|last=Levin|first=Dan|title=Chen Guangcheng Pulls Off Escape, May Be Able to Live Free in China|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/05/02/guangcheng-chen-pulls-off-escape-may-be-able-to-live-free-in-china.html|accessdate=20 November 2012|newspaper=Newsweek|date=2 May 2012}} On 27 April, Chen appeared in an internet video in which he expressed his concern that the authorities would carry out "insane retribution" on his family{{cite news|author=Jonathan Watts |title=Chinese activist fears 'insane retribution' on family after escape |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/apr/27/chinese-activist-fears-insane-retribution?newsfeed=true |accessdate=27 April 2012 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=27 April 2012 |archivedate=28 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120428055009/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/apr/27/chinese-activist-fears-insane-retribution?newsfeed=true |deadurl=no |location=London |df=dmy }} and made three demands of Premier [[Wen Jiabao]]: 1) that local officials who allegedly assaulted his family be prosecuted; 2) that his family's safety be guaranteed; and 3) that the Chinese government prosecute corruption cases under the law. ''The New York Times'' described the situation as a "diplomatic quandary" at a time when the U.S. was seeking to improve relations with China and seeks its support with respect to crises in Iran, Sudan, Syria, and North Korea.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/28/world/asia/chen-guangcheng-blind-lawyer-escapes-house-arrest-china.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1&hp |title=Challenge for U.S. After Escape by China Activist |author=Andrew Jacobs and Jonathan Ansfield |date=27 April 2012 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=27 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIHyYJhQ?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/28/world/asia/chen-guangcheng-blind-lawyer-escapes-house-arrest-china.html?pagewanted=1&_r=2&hp&# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} [[BBC News]] described Chen's escape as coming at "an unwelcome time for China's leaders," who were still dealing with a high-profile [[Wang Lijun incident|corruption scandal]] that resulted in the removal of politburo member [[Bo Xilai]]. Within twenty-four hours, Chen's name as well as the phrases "CGC" and "the blind man" had been blocked by Chinese online censors in an effort to quell Internet discussion of the case.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17865439 |title=Activists debate China lawyer Chen Guangcheng's escape |author=Helier Chung |date=27 April 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=27 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIIl31Dh?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17865439 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On the day Chen announced his escape, Chinese state media did not carry "a single line of news" referring to it.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/apr/27/chinese-media-fails-report-escape-activist?intcmp=239 |title=How Chinese authorities barred my visit to Chen Guangcheng |author=Jonathan Watts |date=27 April 2012 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=27 April 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIIpILgX?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/apr/27/chinese-media-fails-report-escape-activist?intcmp=239 |deadurl=no |location=London |df=dmy-all }} ''The New York Times'' wrote that news of the escape "electrified China’s rights activists".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/world/asia/flight-of-chen-guangcheng-chinese-rights-lawyer-thrills-dissidents.html?_r=1&hp# |title=Flight of Chinese Rights Lawyer Thrills Dissidents |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CII9W6rb?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/29/world/asia/flight-of-chen-guangcheng-chinese-rights-lawyer-thrills-dissidents.html?_r=2&hp&# |deadurl=no |author=Andrew Jacobs |date=28 April 2012 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=28 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }} === Negotiations and exit from U.S. embassy === [[File:Chen Guangcheng in hospital.jpg|thumb|Chen Guangcheng with his family at a hospital in Beijing, China, on 2 May 2012]] [[Kurt M. Campbell]], an assistant secretary of state, quietly arrived in Beijing on 29 April for negotiations with representatives of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.{{cite news |title=In Crisis Over Dissident, U.S. Sends Official to Beijing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/30/world/asia/us-official-in-beijing-to-discuss-chen-guangcheng.html |accessdate=29 April 2012 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=29 April 2012 |author=Steven Lee Myers |author2=Jane Perlez |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIIVulhB?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/30/world/asia/us-official-in-beijing-to-discuss-chen-guangcheng.html?_r=0# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} After several days of media speculation as to his whereabouts, Chen was confirmed on 2 May to have been under U.S diplomatic protection at the Embassy.{{cite news|title=Chen Guangcheng breaks silence with phone call to The Washington Post |author=Keith B. Richburg |date=2 May 2012 |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/chen-guangcheng-breaks-silence-with-phone-call-to-the-washington-post/2012/05/02/gIQA0dMJwT_story.html |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIIpd5aQ?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/chen-guangcheng-breaks-silence-with-phone-call-to-the-washington-post/2012/05/02/gIQA0dMJwT_story.html |deadurl=no |accessdate=2 May 2012 |df=dmy }} According to embassy representatives, the agreement brokered with Chinese authorities provided that Chen would be freed from [[soft detention]], relocated, and be permitted to finish his legal education at one of several law schools in China. Chinese officials also promised to investigate "extra-legal activities" taken by Shandong province authorities against Chen and his family.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/02/us-usa-china-statement-idUSBRE8410K920120502 |title=U.S. statements on China dissident Chen Guangcheng |date=2 May 2012 |author=Chris Buckley |agency=Reuters |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJ0xqS5?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/02/us-usa-china-statement-idUSBRE8410K920120502 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Chen left the embassy of his own accord on 2 May, was reunited with his family, and admitted to Beijing's Chaoyang Hospital for medical treatment.{{cite news |title=Blind Chinese Dissident Leaves U.S. Embassy for Medical Treatment |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/03/world/asia/chen-guangcheng-leaves-us-embassy-in-beijing-china.html |accessdate=2 May 2012 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=2 May 2012 |author=Jane Perlez |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIIpzhRk?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/03/world/asia/chen-guangcheng-leaves-us-embassy-in-beijing-china.html?_r=0# |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} During the initial negotiations in the U.S. embassy, Chen did not request asylum in the United States or considered leaving China, but instead demanded to remain there as a free man. However, soon after leaving the embassy, Chen feared that Chinese authorities would renege on their promises or take punitive actions against his family members. While in the hospital, Chinese security personnel barred U.S. diplomatic staff from meeting with him. Rumors emerged that Chinese officials had coerced Chen into leaving the embassy by threatening his family.{{cite news|author=David Pierson and Paul Richter |title=Friend says activist left U.S. Embassy due to threats to family |date=2 May 2012 |accessdate=2 May 2012 |work=Los Angeles Times |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/05/blind-activist-embassy-threats.html |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJ1KO9N?url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/05/blind-activist-embassy-threats.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} U.S. negotiators stated that while in the embassy, Chen had been told by Chinese officials that if he sought asylum in the United States, his wife and daughter would likely remain under house arrest in Shandong. However, they maintained that they had not heard of the threats from local officials that his family would be beaten, and that they had not communicated such a message to Chen.{{cite news |title=The Chen Guangcheng Affair: U.S. Denies China Dissident's Account of Coercion |author=Jay Newton-Small |accessdate=10 August 2012 |work=Time |date=2 May 2012 |url=http://swampland.time.com/2012/05/02/the-chen-guangcheng-affair-u-s-denies-china-dissidents-account-of-coercion/?iid=sl-main-lede#ixzz1tkTKUNdA |archivedate=13 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713011455/http://swampland.time.com/2012/05/02/the-chen-guangcheng-affair-u-s-denies-china-dissidents-account-of-coercion/?iid=sl-main-lede#ixzz1tkTKUNdA |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 3 May, Chen clarified to the [[BBC]] that he had become aware of the threats against his family after leaving the embassy, and at that point changed his mind about wishing to stay in China.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17938930 |title=China's Chen Guangcheng 'unable to meet US officials' |date=3 May 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2 May 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJDgKlz?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17938930 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 2 May, a spokesperson of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs demanded that the U.S. apologize for the Chen incident, investigate its acts and never interfere in China's domestic matters in such a way again.[http://thinkingchinese.com/Chinas-Ministry-of-Foreign-Affairs-demands-that-the-US-apologizes-for-the-Chen-Guangcheng-incident 外交部要求美方就陈光诚一事向中方道歉 – The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs demands that the US apologizes for the Chen Guangcheng incident] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJDqZvW?url=http://thinkingchinese.com/Chinas-Ministry-of-Foreign-Affairs-demands-that-the-US-apologizes-for-the-Chen-Guangcheng-incident |date=19 November 2012 }} (bilingual), [http://thinkingchinese.com/ Thinking Chinese]. May 2012. [https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJDqZvW?url=http://thinkingchinese.com/Chinas-Ministry-of-Foreign-Affairs-demands-that-the-US-apologizes-for-the-Chen-Guangcheng-incident Archived] from the original on 19 November 2012. Retrieved 10 August 2012. In an editorial on 4 May, ''[[Beijing Daily]]'' described Chen as "a tool and a pawn for American politicians to denigrate China".{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/04/us-china-usa-paper-idUSBRE8430BE20120504 |title=China paper calls Chen a U.S. pawn; envoy is a 'troublemaker' |author=Chris Buckley |date=4 May 2012 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=4 May 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJMmC3m?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/04/us-china-usa-paper-idUSBRE8430BE20120504 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The daily also accused US Ambassador Gary Locke of stirring up trouble by sheltering Chen, and questioned Locke's motives.Priscilla Jiao. (18 May 2012). "Locke calls daily's bluff by declaring his assets". ''South China Morning Post''. On 4 May, after Chen made clear his desire to leave China for the United States, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson indicated that, if he wished to study abroad, he could "apply through normal channels to the relevant departments in accordance with the law, just like any other Chinese citizen."Andrew Quinn and Terril Yue Jones (4 May 2012). [https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFBRE84101120120504 "China says dissident may apply to study in U.S"]. Reuters. 4 May 2012. [https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJQxYZY?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/04/oukwd-uk-china-usa-idAFBRE84101120120504 Archived] from the original on 19 November 2012. Retrieved 10 August 2012. On the same day, Chen was offered a [[visiting scholar]] position at [[New York University]].{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304752804577384230921731416 |title=NYU Offers Position to Activist |author=Lisa Fleisher |date=4 May 2012 |work=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=4 May 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJRcT1G?url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304752804577384230921731416.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 19 May, Chen, his wife, and his two children, having been granted [[U.S. visa]]s, departed Beijing on a commercial flight for [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], [[New Jersey]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/20/world/asia/chen-guangcheng-set-to-leave-china-for-united-states.html?hp |work=The New York Times |date=19 May 2012 |author=Andrew Jacobs |title=Blind Chinese Dissident Leaves on Flight for U.S. |accessdate=19 May 2012 |archivedate=21 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120521051100/http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/20/world/asia/china-dissident-chen-guangcheng-united-states.html?hp |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-18127886 |publisher=BBC News |date=19 May 2012 |title=China dissident Chen Guangcheng heads for US |accessdate=19 May 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJhZmgu?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-18127886 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} === Treatment of family and associates === While Chen was living under house arrest, several of his family members also reportedly faced harassment and confinement by authorities. His elderly mother, Wang Jinxiang, recalled being continuously followed by three security agents.{{cite web|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2012/06/09/151801/chen-guangchengs-mother-brother.html |title=Chen Guangcheng’s mother, brother talk after China pulls security from Dongshigu |author=Tom Lasseter |date=9 June 2012 |publisher=McClatchy |accessdate=18 November 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIKXxU0O?url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2012/06/09/151801/chen-guangchengs-mother-brother.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The BBC reported in May 2012 that she remained under house arrest.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17949462 |title=Chen Guangcheng's support network |date=19 November 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=18 November 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIKcjQP1?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-17949462 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Before leaving China in the spring of 2012, Chen expressed concern that his relatives and other activists who had helped him evade capture would be punished by Chinese officials after his departure. On 27 April 2012, soon after Chen escaped house arrest, plainclothes security agents forced entry into the home of his eldest brother, Chen Guangfu. Believing that the elder brother had information on Chen's escape, police took him to a police station for interrogation, and reportedly chained his feet, slapped him, and struck him with a belt.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/24/chen-guangcheng-brother-flees-captors |title=Chen Guangcheng brother escapes to tell of beatings and reprisals |author=Tania Branigan |date=24 May 2012 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=18 November 2012 |archivedate=19 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150119104013/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/24/chen-guangcheng-brother-flees-captors |deadurl=no |location=London}} Police officers then allegedly returned to the family's home and proceeded to beat Guangfu's wife and son. His son, Chen Kegui, pulled a knife and slashed at three of the officers, causing minor injuries. He was taken into custody and faces criminal charges for attempted murder. On 24 May, it was reported that Chen Guangfu had escaped to Beijing from his guarded village to advocate on behalf of his son.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/25/world/asia/brother-of-chen-guangcheng-escapes-guarded-village.html?_r=1 |title=Brother of Chinese Dissident Escapes Guarded Village |work=The New York Times |author=Andrew Jacobs |date=24 May 2012 |accessdate=25 May 2012 |archivedate=30 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120530103214/http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/25/world/asia/brother-of-chen-guangcheng-escapes-guarded-village.html?_r=1 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In November 2012, Chen Kegui was sentenced to more than three years in prison.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-20551967 |title=Chen Guangcheng: Nephew Chen Kegui sentenced |date=30 November 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=30 November 2012 |archivedate=30 November 2012|archiveurl= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-20551967 |deadurl=no}} On 4 November 2013, Chen Guangfu said he would fly to New York City with his mother two days later for a reunion with his brother Chen Guangcheng.{{cite web|url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/international/230595491_Family_members_to_visit_blind_China_activist_in_US.html |title=Family members to visit blind China activist in US |publisher=North Jersey Media Group, Associated Press |date=4 November 2013 |accessdate=5 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105075006/http://www.northjersey.com/news/international/230595491_Family_members_to_visit_blind_China_activist_in_US.html |archivedate=5 November 2013 |df=dmy }} == In the United States == [[File:Pelosi with Chen Guangcheng.jpg|thumb|[[United States House of Representatives|US Representative]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] meets with Chen Guangcheng in New York in June 2012]] Following his arrival in the U.S., Chen, his wife, and the couple's two children settled in a housing complex for students and faculty of [[New York University]], located in [[Greenwich Village]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2147348/Chen-Guangcheng-enjoys-new-life-New-York.html |work=Daily Mail |date=20 May 2012 |title=Free at last: Blind Chinese activist Chen Guangcheng enjoys new life in New York as he takes family to playground |accessdate=21 May 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJgrWm6?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2147348/Chen-Guangcheng-Blind-Chinese-activist-enjoys-new-life-New-York.html |deadurl=no |location=London |df=dmy }} He reportedly began studying English for two hours per day, in addition to having regular meetings with American legal scholars.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/19/world/asia/chen-guangcheng-is-safe-in-new-york-but-thinks-of-china.html?smid=pl-share|work=The New York Times|date=18 June 2012|author=Erik Eckholm|title=Even in New York, China Casts a Shadow|accessdate=19 June 2012|archivedate=19 November 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJkMLcL?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/19/world/asia/chen-guangcheng-is-safe-in-new-york-but-thinks-of-china.html?smid=pl-share&_r=0#|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} His memoir, ''The Barefoot Lawyer'', was published in March 2015 by [[Henry Holt and Company]].http://www.indiebound.org/book/9780805098051?aff=henryholt1{{cite book|title=The barefoot lawyer : a blind man's fight for justice and freedom in China|year=2015|ISBN=978-0-8050-9805-1|OCLC=877905690}}''The Barefoot Lawyer: A Blind Man's Fight for Justice and Freedom in China'' On 29 May 2012, Chen published an editorial in the ''New York Times'' criticizing the Chinese government and the Communist Party for the "lawless punishment inflicted on (himself) and (his) family over the past seven years." He said that "those who handled my case were able to openly flout the nation’s laws in many ways for many years."{{cite news |author=Chen Guangcheng |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/30/opinion/how-china-flouts-its-laws.html?_r=1 |title=How China Flouts Its Laws |work=The New York Times |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=7 June 2012 |archivedate=2 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120602014616/http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/30/opinion/how-china-flouts-its-laws.html?_r=1 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In an April 2013 testimony before the [[House Foreign Affairs Committee]], Chen said that Chinese authorities had failed to deliver on promises to investigate allegations of mistreatment against him and his family.Peter Foster, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/9982730/Chinas-new-leaders-will-not-bring-change-says-blind-lawyer-Chen-Guangcheng.html "China's new leaders will not bring change, says blind lawyer Chen Guangcheng"], ''The Telegraph'', 9 April 2013. Chen issued a statement in June saying NYU is forcing him to leave at the end of June because of pressure from the Chinese government.{{cite web |title=CHINESE ACTIVIST SAYS HE'S BEING FORCED OUT BY NYU |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/chinese-activist-says-hes-being-forced-out-nyu |publisher=AP |accessdate=17 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625205850/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/chinese-activist-says-hes-being-forced-out-nyu |archivedate=25 June 2013 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/plot-thickens-meet-colorful-cast-103946298.html|title=The plot thickens: Meet the colorful cast of characters in the Chen Guangcheng saga|first=Jake Maxwell|last=Watts|work=Quartz|publisher=Yahoo News|date=2013-06-21|accessdate=2013-06-28}} This claim was denied by the university, as well as by professor [[Jerome A. Cohen]], Chen's mentor who arranged for his placement at NYU. Chen's close association with conservative Christian and [[United States pro-life movement|pro-life]] figures since coming to the United States, including representative [[Chris Smith (New Jersey politician)|Chris Smith]], pastor [[Bob Fu]], and media consultant [[Mark Corallo]], has concerned old supporters like Cohen.{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1263925/friends-fear-right-wing-connections-will-hit-chen-guangchengs-credibility|title=Friends fear right-wing connections will hit Chen Guangcheng's credibility|first=Verna|last=Yu|date=2013-06-19|accessdate=2013-06-28|publisher=South China Morning Post}}{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2013/06/19/mystifying-blind-activists-adviser-speaks-out-on-pressure-claims/|title=Blind Activist’s Former Adviser: Pressure Claims ‘Mystifying’|date=2013-06-19|accessdate=2013-06-28|publisher=The Wall Street Journal}} In October 2013, Chen accepted an offer from the [[Witherspoon Institute]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey|Princeton]], [[New Jersey]], which opposes [[abortion]] and [[gay marriage]]. Chen became a Distinguished Senior Fellow in Human Rights at the Witherspoon Institute,http://winst.org/2013/10/chen-guangcheng/ as well as a Visiting Fellow of the Institute for Policy Research and Catholic Studies at the Catholic University of America {{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/chinese-human-rights-activist-joins-catholic-university/2013/10/02/f8c868bc-2b8b-11e3-8ade-a1f23cda135e_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Pamela | last=Constable | title=Chinese human rights activist Chen Guangcheng joins Catholic University | date=3 October 2013}} and a Senior Distinguished Advisor to the [[Lantos Foundation for Human Rights and Justice]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lantosfoundation.org/Lantos_News_Template.asp?id=182 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004231531/http://www.lantosfoundation.org/Lantos_News_Template.asp?id=182 |archivedate=4 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }} On 16 October 2013, Chen made his first public appearance in his role as a Distinguished Senior Fellow at the Witherspoon Institute. He delivered a public lecture at [[Princeton University]] entitled "China and the World in the 21st Century: The Next Human Rights Revolution,"{{cite web |url=http://dailyprincetonian.com/news/2013/10/chinese-dissident-chen-guangcheng-advocates-universal-human-rights/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-04-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414045416/http://dailyprincetonian.com/news/2013/10/chinese-dissident-chen-guangcheng-advocates-universal-human-rights/ |archivedate=14 April 2016 |df=dmy-all }} which was co-sponsored by the Witherspoon Institutehttp://winst.org/2013/10/chen-guangcheng/#more-1096 and the James Madison Program in American Ideals and Institutions.http://web.princeton.edu/sites/jmadison/calendar/documents/Flyer%202013%201016%20CHEN%20Guangcheng.pdf The text of Chen's speech, translated into English, was then published online.http://www.thepublicdiscourse.com/2013/10/11049/ In the speech, Chen called on the American people to support the Chinese people by fighting against the oppressive Communist government of China. He reminded the audience that even small actions undertaken in defense of human rights can have a large impact, because “Every person has infinite strength. Every action has an important impact. We must believe in the value of our own actions.” == Awards and recognition == [[File:Chen Guangcheng on Legislative Yuan.jpg|thumb|Chen in [[Legislative Yuan]], [[Taiwan]].]] Chen began attracting international media attention for his civil rights activism in the early 2000s. In March 2002, Newsweek magazine ran a cover story on Chen and the "[[barefoot lawyer]]" movement in China, detailing his advocacy on behalf of villagers and the disabled. His profile rose further in 2005 when he filed a landmark class-action suit taking on abuses of the one-child policy. In 2007, Chen Guangcheng was named one of the [[Time 100|''Time'' 100]], ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'''s annual list of "100 men and women whose power, talent or moral example is transforming our world". The citation stated, "He may have lost his sight as a child, but Chen Guangcheng's legal vision has helped illuminate the plight of thousands of Chinese villagers." Later that year, Chen won the [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] while still in detention.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/02/world/asia/02iht-phils.1.6954445.html |title=Ramon Magsaysay Award recipients announced |date=2 August 2007 |author=Carlos Conde |work=The New York Times |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIJzsaNk?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/02/world/asia/02iht-phils.1.6954445.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The award, often called the "Asian Nobel Prize", was bestowed for "his irrepressible passion for justice in leading ordinary Chinese citizens to assert their legitimate rights under the law".{{cite news| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2479&dat=20070818&id=hlM1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=YyUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1019,864999 | title =Blind Chinese leads way in fight for rights of poor | date = 18 August 2007 | author = E.K. Santos |work=Philippine Daily Inquirer |accessdate=10 August 2012}} According to AIDS activist [[Hu Jia (activist)|Hu Jia]], Chen's wife Yuan Weijing attempted to attend the Magsaysay Award ceremony on her husband's behalf, her passport was revoked and her mobile phone was confiscated by Chinese authorities at [[Beijing Capital International Airport]].{{cite news|author=Ben Blanchard |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUKPEK23857720070824 |title=China stops activist's wife leaving country |agency=Reuters |date=24 August 2007 |accessdate=16 December 2011 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIKH5Ti9?url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2007/08/24/uk-china-activist-idUKPEK23857720070824 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The [[National Endowment for Democracy]] honored Chen with the 2008 Democracy Award. Chen was one of seven Chinese lawyers and civil rights activists to be named as recipients of the award.{{cite web|url=http://www.ned.org/docs/08annual/PDFs/AR_NewsEvents08.pdf |title=2008 Democracy Award |year=2008 |publisher=National Endowment for Democracy |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIKHPY8R?url=http://www.ned.org/docs/08annual/PDFs/AR_NewsEvents08.pdf |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In 2012, Chen was chosen as the recipient of the Human Rights Award from the New York-based NGO [[Human Rights First]]. In explaining the choice, the organization's president Elisa Massimino stated, "Mr. Chen's activism has reignited an international conversation about the need to protect human rights lawyers around the world who face great danger for their courageous work."{{cite web |url=http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/2012/06/28/chen-guangcheng-chosen-for-2012-human-rights-award/ |title=Chen Guangcheng Chosen for 2012 Human Rights Award |date=28 June 2012 |publisher=Human Rights First |accessdate=10 August 2012 |archivedate=19 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIKI8pkJ?url=http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/2012/06/28/chen-guangcheng-chosen-for-2012-human-rights-award/# |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} In 2014 he received the [[Geneva Summit for Human Rights and Democracy|Geneva Summit]] Courage Award.{{cite web|title=Program 25 February 2014|url=http://www.genevasummit.org/program/6/2014|website=Geneva Summit for Human Rights and Democracy|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227231231/http://www.genevasummit.org/program/6/2014|archivedate=27 February 2015|df=dmy-all}} == References == {{Redirect|CHORI||Chori (disambiguation)}} {{primarysources|date=July 2008}} {{Infobox institute |name =Children's Hospital Oakland Research Institute (CHORI) |image =University High School (Oakland, CA).jpg |image_name = |image_size = |image_alt = |caption =CHORI North Campus |motto = |founder = |established ={{Start date|1959}} |mission = |focus = |president = |chairman = |head_label = |head = |faculty = 55 |adjunct_faculty = |staff = 280 |key_people = |budget = |endowment = |former_name = Bruce Lyon Memorial Research Laboratory (BLMRL) |location = [[Oakland]], [[California]] |city =[[Oakland]] |state =[[California|CA]] |country =USA |coor ={{Coord|37|50|33|N|122|16|10|W|dim:1000|display=inline|name=CHORI}} |address =5700 Martin Luther King Jr. Way Oakland, CA 94609 |website ={{URL |http://www.chori.org}} }}
'''Children's Hospital Oakland Research Institute''' ('''CHORI''') is a biomedical research institute affiliated with California’s pediatric medical center, [[Children's Hospital Oakland|UCSF Benioff Children's Hospital Oakland]].
CHORI is based in [[Oakland, California]], and operates a {{convert|100000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} biomedical research facility that houses 300 staff members. It includes eight [http://www.chori.org/Centers/Centers_Intro/intro_centers.html research centers] that conduct focused research on [[cancer]], [[critical care medicine]], [[genetics]], [[immunobiology]] and [[vaccine]] development, [[Marrow_Transplantation|blood and marrow transplantation]] and [[Cellular_therapy|cellular therapies]], [[nutrition]] and [[metabolism]], prevention of [[obesity]], [[cardiovascular disease]] and [[diabetes]], [[sickle cell disease]] and [[thalassemia]].
The [[National Institutes of Health]] is CHORI's primary funding source.
== Research Centers == * Center for Cancer * Center for Critical Care Medicine * Center for Genetics * Center for Immunobiology & Vaccine Development * The Jordan Family Center for Blood and Marrow Transplantation and Cellular Therapies Research * Center for Nutrition & Metabolism * Center for Prevention of Obesity, Cardiovascular Disease & Diabetes * Center for Sickle Cell Disease & Thalassemia
== Research Services == * BACPAC Resource Center * Cell Sorting * Elemental Analysis * Genetic Testing * Mass Spectrometry * Microscope Imaging * Molecular Diagnostics * Sibling Donor Cord Blood
== Research Applications == CHORI’s translational research applications include providing cures for blood diseases, developing new vaccines for infectious diseases, and discovering new treatment protocols for previously fatal or debilitating conditions such as cancers, sickle cell disease and thalassemia, diabetes, asthma, HIV/AIDS, pediatric obesity, nutritional deficiencies, birth defects, hemophilia and cystic fibrosis. CHORI is also a teaching institute [http://www.chori.org/Education/Introduction/education_training.html] with educational programs for high school, college, doctoral and post-doctoral students.
== Research Achievements == CHORI is the first research institute in North America to transplant and cure a child with [[Alpha-thalassemia|alpha thalassemia major]], is a leading center for the use of cord blood and bone marrow transplantation in children with sickle cell anemia and thalassemia, and offers the only not-for-profit Sibling Donor Cord Blood Program in the world. The Research Institute’s recombinant DNA library contains over 20 million DNA samples that are used in research programs around the world.
== History == CHORI began in 1959 with a small group of scientists and initial financial support from Children’s Hospital Oakland and the family of Lt. Bruce Lyon. Founded as the Bruce Lyon Memorial Research Laboratory (BLMRL), it was the first research laboratory in Northern California dedicated exclusively to children’s diseases. BLMRL was renamed “CHORI,” the research branch of the newly named [http://www.childrenshospitaloakland.org/ Children's Hospital & Research Center Oakland], in 1986. In 1999, CHORI moved to the former [[University_High_School_(Oakland,_California)|University High School]] campus, where it is currently located.

{{About|the animal|the disease known as crab lice|Pediculosis pubis}} {{Taxobox | name = Crab louse | image = Crab louse (251 23) Female, from a human host.jpg | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Arthropod]]a | classis = [[Insect]]a | ordo = [[Phthiraptera]] | subordo = [[Anoplura]] | familia = [[Pthiridae]] | genus = ''[[Pthirus]]'' | species = '''''P. pubis''''' | binomial = ''Pthirus pubis'' | binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]]) | synonyms = ''Pediculus pubis'' <small>Linnaeus, 1758</small> }} The '''crab louse''' or '''pubic louse''' (''Pthirus pubis'') is an [[insect]] that is an [[obligate parasite|obligate]] [[parasite|ectoparasite]] of [[human]]s, feeding exclusively on [[blood]].<ref name="Bolognia">{{cite book |author1=Rapini, Ronald P. |author2=Bolognia, Jean L. |author3=Jorizzo, Joseph L. |title=Dermatology: 2-Volume Set |publisher=Mosby |location=St. Louis |year=2007 |pages= |isbn=1-4160-2999-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> The crab louse usually is found in the person's [[pubic hair]]. Although the louse cannot jump, it can also live in other areas of the body that are covered with coarse hair, such as the [[eyelash]]es.<ref name="Prevention">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/lice/index.html|title=CDC - Lice|last=Prevention|first=CDC - Centers for Disease Control and|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-12-04}}{{PD-notice}}</ref><ref name="cdc.gov">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/lice/pubic/index.html|title=Lice: Pubic|last=Prevention|first=CDC - Centers for Disease Control and|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-12-04}}{{PD-notice}}</ref> It is of the order [[Psocodea]].
Humans are the only known hosts of the crab louse, although a closely related species, ''[[Pthirus gorillae]]'', infects [[gorilla]] populations. The human parasite diverged from ''Pthirus gorillae'' approximately 3.3 million years ago.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=J Biol |date=10 February 2009 |volume=8 |issue=2 |pages=20 |title=Apes, lice and prehistory |author=Weiss RA |pmid=19232074 |pmc=2687769 |doi=10.1186/jbiol114}}</ref> It is more distantly related to the genus ''Pediculus'', which contains the human [[head louse|head]] and [[body louse|body lice]] and a louse that affects [[chimpanzee]]s and [[bonobo]]s.
==Naming== Infestation with crab lice is also called ''phthiriasis'' or ''phthiriasis pubis''. The disease (like the name of the [[order (biology)|order]] to which the louse belongs, Phthiraptera) is spelled with ''phth'', but the scientific name of the louse, ''Pthirus pubis'', is spelled with ''pth'', despite this being based on a misspelling that was nevertheless fixed as the official spelling in 1958.<ref>[http://phthiraptera.info/content/taxonomy-human-lice Taxonomy of Human Lice]</ref>
==Description== An adult crab louse is about 1.3–2 mm long (slightly smaller than the [[body louse]] and [[head louse]]), and can be distinguished from those other species by its almost round body. Another distinguishing feature is that the rearmost two pairs of legs of a crab louse are much thicker than the front legs and have large claws.<ref name="service">{{cite book |author=Service, Mike |title=Medical Entomology for Students|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|year=2012 |pages= |edition=5th|isbn=978-1-107-66818-8 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==Life cycle== The eggs of the crab louse are laid usually on the coarse hairs of the genital and perianal regions of the human body. Crab lice may also be found on other areas of the body that have coarse and relatively sparse coverings of hair, such as the beard, moustache, eyelashes, and underneath the arms. They do not generally occur on the finer hair of the scalp.<ref name="service"/><ref name=1a>{{cite journal|last=Nuttall|first=GHF|title=The biology of Phthirus pubis|journal=Parasitology|year=1918|volume=10|pages=383–405|doi=10.1017/s0031182000003954}}</ref>
The female lays about three eggs a day. The eggs take 6–8 days to hatch, and there are three [[nymph (biology)|nymphal]] stages which together take 10–17 days before the adult develops, making a total life cycle from egg to adult of 16–25 days. Adults live for up to 30 days.<ref name="service"/> Crab lice feed exclusively on blood, and take a blood meal 4–5 times daily. Adults are 1.5–2.0 mm long and flattened. They are much broader in comparison to head and body lice. Adults are found only on the human host and require human blood to survive. If adults are forced off the host, they will die within 24–48 hours without a blood feeding. Pubic lice are transmitted from person to person most-commonly via sexual contact, although fomites (bedding, clothing) may play a minor role in their transmission.<ref name=":0"/>
==Infestation of humans== {{Main|Pediculosis pubis}} [[File:Pubic lice on eye-lashes.jpg|thumb|Pubic lice on [[eyelash]]es]]
Infestations of crab lice are known as [[pediculosis pubis]] or phthiriasis pubis (which, unlike the generic name of the louse, is spelled with a ''phth''). Infestation of the eyelashes is referred to as pediculosis ciliaris or phthiriasis palpebrarum.<ref>Manjunatha NP, Jayamanne GR, Desai SP, Moss TR, Lalik J, Woodland A. Pediculosis pubis: presentation to ophthalmologist as phthriasis palpebrarum associated with corneal epithelial keratitis. Int. J. STD AIDS 2006; 17: 424–426</ref>
The main symptom of infestation with crab lice is [[itch]]ing, usually in the pubic-hair area, resulting from [[hypersensitivity]] to louse saliva, which can become stronger over two or more weeks following initial infestation. In some infestations, a characteristic grey-blue or slate coloration appears (''maculae caeruleae'') at the feeding site, which may last for several days.
[[File:Crab egg.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Crab louse egg on human body hair]]
Current worldwide prevalence has been estimated at 2% of the human population, but accurate numbers are difficult to gauge because crab lice infestations are not considered a reportable condition by many governments, and many cases are self-treated or treated discreetly by primary physicians.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Anderson AL, Chaney E |title=Pubic lice (''Pthirus pubis''): history, biology and treatment vs. knowledge and beliefs of US college students |journal=Int J Environ Res Public Health |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=592–600 |date=February 2009 |pmid=19440402 |pmc=2672365 |doi=10.3390/ijerph6020592 }}</ref>
Crab lice usually infect a new host only by close contact between individuals, usually through [[sexual intercourse]]. Adults are more frequently infested than children. Non-sexual transmissions may occur among family and roommates through the use of shared towels, clothing, beds or closets. They can only survive a short time away from the warmth and humidity of the human body.
It has been suggested that an increasing percentage of humans [[Body grooming|removing]] their [[pubic hair]] has led to reduced crab louse populations in some parts of the world.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Armstrong|first1 = N. R.|last2 = Wilson|first2 = J. D. |title = Did the "Brazilian" kill the pubic louse?|doi = 10.1136/sti.2005.018671|journal = Sexually Transmitted Infections|volume = 82|issue = 3|pages = 265–266|year = 2006|pmid = 16731684|pmc =2564756}}</ref><ref>Bloomberg: [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-13/brazilian-bikini-waxes-make-crab-lice-endangered-species-health.html Brazilian bikini waxes make crab lice endangered species], published 13 January 2013, retrieved 14 January 2013</ref> Other lice that infest humans are the [[body louse]] and the [[head louse]]. The claws of these three species are adapted to attachment to specific hair diameters.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/779244257|title=Williams gynecology|last=|first=|date=2012|publisher=McGraw-Hill Medical|others=Hoffman, Barbara L., Williams, J. Whitridge (John Whitridge), 1866-1931.|year=|isbn=9780071716727|edition=2nd|location=New York|pages=90|oclc=779244257}}</ref>
[[File:Crab Lice CDC.png|thumb|left|300px|Crab Lice]] Pubic lice are not known to transmit disease. Adult pubic lice are 1.1–1.8 mm in length. The pubic hair can typically host up to a dozen on average. Pubic lice typically are found attached to hair in the pubic area but sometimes are found on coarse hair elsewhere on the body (for example, [[eyebrow]]s, [[eyelashes]], [[beard]], [[mustache]], [[chest]], [[armpits]], etc.). Crab lice attach to pubic hair that is thicker than other body hair because their claws are adapted to the specific diameter of pubic hair.<ref name=":1" /> Pubic lice infestations ([[Pediculosis pubis|pthiriasis]]) are usually spread through [[Human sexual activity|sexual contact]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/779244257|title=Williams gynecology|date=2012|publisher=McGraw-Hill Medical|others=Hoffman, Barbara L., Williams, J. Whitridge (John Whitridge), 1866-1931.|isbn=9780071716727|edition=2nd|location=New York|oclc=779244257}}</ref><ref name="Prevention"/><ref name="cdc.gov"/> The crab louse can travel up to 10 inches on the body. Pubic lice infestation is found worldwide and occurs in all races and ethnic groups and in all economic levels. Pubic lice usually are spread through sexual contact and are most common in adults. Occasionally pubic lice may be spread by close personal contact or contact with articles such as clothing, bed linens, and towels that have been used by an infested person.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/lice/pubic/epi.html|title=CDC - Lice - Pubic|last=Prevention|first=CDC - Centers for Disease Control and|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-12-04}}{{PD-notice}}</ref> Pubic lice found on the head or eyelashes of children may be an indication of sexual exposure or abuse. Pubic lice do not transmit disease; however, secondary [[Pathogenic bacteria|bacterial infection]] can occur from scratching of the skin.They are much broader in comparison to head and body lice. Adults are found only on the human host and require human [[blood]] to survive. If adults are forced off the host, they will die within 24–48 hours without a blood feeding.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/lice/pubic/biology.html|title=CDC - Lice - Pubic|last=Prevention|first=CDC - Centers for Disease Control and|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-12-04}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
Symptoms of crab louse infestation in the pubic area include itching, redness and inflammation. These symptoms cause increased blood circulation to the skin of the pubic region creating a blood-rich environment for the crab louse. Pubic lice infestation can also be diagnosed by identifying the presence of nits or eggs on the pubic hair. When clinicans find the crab louse on one family member they often request to examine other members of the family for similar symptoms of infestation. If a clinician suspects the presence of the louse, they may be able to identify the nits or eggs under magnification.<ref name=":1" />

{{Infobox deity | type = Irish | name = Dian Cecht
[[god of healing]] | image = | caption = | member_of = the [[Tuatha Dé Danann]] | abodes = | weapons = | animals = | symbols = | festivals = | parents = Esarg or the [[Dagda]] | siblings = | consorts = | children = Cu, Cethen, [[Cian]], [[Miach]], [[Airmed]], Étan, Ochtriullach }} In [[Irish mythology]], '''Dian Cécht''' ([[Old Irish language|Old Irish]] pronunciation {{IPA-sga|dʲiːən kʲeːxt|}}; also known as ''Cainte'' or ''Canta'') was the [[god of healing]], the healer for the [[Tuatha Dé Danann]]. He was the father of Cu, Cethen and [[Cian]].{{cite book|last=Reidling|first=Kisma|title=Faery-Faith Traditional Wisdom|volume=Irish Cosmology & Faery Glamoury|publisher=AuthorHouse|date=3 November 2004}} His other children were [[Miach]], [[Airmed]], Étan the poet and Ochtriullach.{{cite book|title=''[[Lebor Gabála Érenn]]''|volume=IV|publisher=Irish Texts Society|location=Dublin|year=1941}}{{cite book|title=''Cath Maige Tuireadh''|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/cmt/cmteng.htm}} Dian Cécht is described as a son of the [[Dagda]] in the Dindsenchas.http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T106500D/index.html Through Cian, he is also [[Lugh]]'s paternal grandfather. He appears in the mythological cycle of medieval Irish tales. ==Etymology== [[Linguistics|Linguistic]] knowledge about regular [[sound change]]s in [[Celtic languages]] (McCone, 1996) and analysis of the [[University of Wales]]’ [[Proto-Celtic]] [[lexicon]] and of [[Julius Pokorny]]’s ''[[Indogermanisches etymologisches Wörterbuch]]'' permit ''*Deino-kwekwto-'' ‘swift concoction’ as a plausible [[Proto-Celtic]] reconstruction for this [[theonym]]. According to the Historical Encyclopedy of Celtic Culture, the name Dian Cecht may be a combination of the Old Irish common words ''dían'' 'swift' and ''cécht'', glossed as 'power'.J. T. Koch, ''Celtic culture: a historical encyclopedia'', Vols. 1-4 - p. 586. However, this may only be a surface etymology or [[Folk etymology|reanalysis]]. ==Curative well== He blessed a well called [[Slane]], located to the west of [[Magh Tuireadh]] and east of Loch Arboch in a place called the Field of the Apple Tree (Achad Abla),https://books.google.com/books?id=4oMZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA488&lpg=PA488&dq=tuirbe+tragmar&source=bl&ots=v7VREOZ0Fz&sig=_yaW8KVe-1tD-U0FqK2rQaCK-Gg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYxOTKzOXOAhVQAx4KHeGGASQQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=tuirbe%20tragmar&f=false where the [[Tuatha Dé]] could bathe when wounded; they became healed and continued fighting. It would heal any wound but [[decapitation]]. ==Boiling of the River Barrow== It was Dian Cecht who once saved Ireland, and was indirectly the cause of the name of the [[River Barrow]].{{cite book|title=Celtic Myth and Legend: The Gaelic Gods|chapter=V. The Gods of the Gaels|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/celt/cml/cml09.htm}} The [[Morrigan|Morrígú]], the heaven-god's fierce wife, had borne a son of such terrible aspect that the physician of the gods, foreseeing danger, counselled that he should be destroyed in his infancy. This was done; and Dian Cecht opened the infant's heart, and found within it three serpents, capable, when they grew to full size, of depopulating Ireland. He lost no time in destroying these serpents also, and burning them into ashes, to avoid the evil which even their dead bodies might do. More than this, he flung the ashes into the nearest river, for he feared that there might be danger even in them; and, indeed, so venomous were they that the river boiled up and slew every living creature in it, and therefore has been called the River Barrow, the ‘Boiling’ ever since. According to the Metrical [[Dindsenchas]]:
'No motion it made The ashes of Meichi the strongly smitten: The stream made sodden and silent past recovery The fell filth of the old serpent. Three turns the serpent made; It sought the soldier to consume him; It would have wasted by its doing the kine; The fell filth of the old serpent. Therefore Diancecht slew it; There rude reason for clean destroying it, For preventing it from wasting Worse than any wolf pack, from consuming utterly. Known to me is the grave where he cast it, A tomb without walls or roof-tree; Its ashes, evil without loveliness or innocence Found silent burial in noble Barrow.https://www.academia.edu/10246879/Indo-European_Dragon-Slayers_and_Healers_and_the_Irish_Account_of_Dian_C%C3%A9cht_and_M%C3%A9iche
This tale in the [[Dindsenchas]] indicates that the being slayed by Diancecht was a serpent named Meichi. Elsewhere the figure named as the slayer of Meichi is [[Mac Cecht]]. ==Healing of Nuada's arm== He made King [[Nuada]] a silver arm which could move and function as a normal arm. Later, Dian Cecht's son, [[Miach]], replaced the silver arm with an arm of flesh and blood, and Dian Cecht killed him out of professional envy. Miach's sister, [[Airmed]], mourned over her brother's grave. As her tears fell, all the healing herbs of the world grew from the grave. Airmed arranged and catalogued the herbs, but then Dian Cécht again reacted with anger and jealousy and scattered the herbs, destroying his daughter's work as well as his son's. For this reason, it is said that no human now knows the healing properties of all the herbs. Dian Cecht was also able to heal [[Mider]] after the latter lost an eye when struck with a twig of hazel.''[[Tochmarc Étaíne]].'' Dian Cecht's healing powers were invoked in [[Ireland]] as late as the 8th century.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==Bibliography== * McCone, Kim (1996). {{Infobox person | name = Don Eladio Sauza | image = Eladio_Sauza.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1883|06|16}} | birth_place = Guadalajara, Mexico | death_date = {{death date and age|1946|07|22|1883|06|16}} | death_place = Guadalajara, Mexico | occupation = Tequila [[Distiller]] }}
'''Don Eladio Sauza''' (June 16, 1883 – July 22, 1946) ran the Sauza Tequila business from 1909 to 1946.
== Early life == Eladio Sauza was born June 16, 1883 in the city of Tequila, Mexico to [[Don Cenobio Sauza]] (1842 – 1909) and Doña Margarita Madrigal Navarro. His father was the founder of the famous [[Sauza Tequila]] distillery.
At age 20 Eladio moved to [[Tecolotlan]] to take charge of his father's distillery, the Hacienda La Labor. There he learned the business of producing and selling [[tequila]]. Later he moved to [[Mazatlán]] in the Northeastern part of Mexico to establish a Sauza Tequila distribution center in order to increase exporting.
== Marriage and children == Eladio married Doña Silveria Mora Enriquez, with whom he had two children: * Francisco Javier Sauza * Carmen Sauza
== Growing Sauza Tequila == In 1909 Eladio returned to Guadalajara to mourn his father's death and to take control of the Sauza Tequila business. Shortly thereafter the [[Mexican Revolution]] threatened to expropriate Eladio's business and farmland. During the Revolution Eladio rallied patriotic sentiment and helped to establish tequila as the official spirit of Mexico.<ref name="In Search of the Blue Agave">[http://www.ianchadwick.com/tequila/20-21st%20centuries.htm In Search of the Blue Agave]</ref>
Eladio modernized and expanded the family business by opening branches in Monterrey and Mexico City, and a concession in Spain.<ref>[http://www.cocktailtimes.com/distillery/sauza.shtml Cocktail Times]</ref>
== Other enterprises == Eladio's interests extended beyond the production of tequila, including: * Establishing a dairy business called Cremeria Moderna that manufactured the ‘Modelo’ butter. * In 1932 he established the first commercial radio station in Guadalajara – XEDQ (no longer in existence). * In 1938 Eladio established the [[Colonial Club]], the first modern nightclub in Guadalajara. * On August 5, 1942 Eladio and other Guadalajara industrial men issued [[El Occidental]], the town's first newspaper.
== The final years == Don Eladio Sauza died on July 22, 1946, at the age of 63. He left the Sauza Tequila business to his firstborn son, [[Don Francisco Javier Sauza|Francisco Javier Sauza]].<ref name="In Search of the Blue Agave"/>
